Of course, this would not be a proper Unfinished Hero book without a lot of danger, a lot of graphic sex and one HOT ALPHA MALE. You get all that and more with RAID. We confess that we re-read KNIGHT and CREED in one day while in the middle of reading RAID. 
 Favorite Quotes: 
 "Prefer to be with a woman who's cute and shy and obviously into me. Means I can save time and get straight to shit that matters." - Raid 
 "I'd crawled across a room for Raiden Miller. And it was him, not me, who stopped it because I didn't like it. Which made me look back and like it." - Hanna 
 Hanna is Raid's reward. 
 We loved this book and would have loved a little more interaction with the other unfinished heroes who appear in this story (this is a stand-alone book but you should read KNIGHT and CREED in that order). With that said, where can we find us a Raiden Ulysses Miller? 
 RaidKristen Ashley
Badass bikers! Sex! Mayhem! Beauty! Coffee! Classic KA. Review to follow. P.S. Hot as fuck Epilogue.Own the WindKristen Ashley

"Sheer beauty." 6 rockin' stars for Ally and Ren's story! 
 What's not to love about Ally Nightingale? She's tough, she's smart, and she feels everything right down to her bones: 
 "Backing up a bit, my name is Allyson Nightingale, but everyone calls me Ally. 
 And I'm a Rock Chick, in name and deed." 
 YES! Everything we absolutely love about the Rock Chick series is packed right into the last installment: gorgeous, real women, hot Alpha heroes and SUPER hot sex! And of course, like the previous Rock Chick stories, Ally vehemently denies her true feelings for the gorgeous Ren, but lucky for Ally (and us!), he knows what he wants, and what Ally wants (and needs), too! 
 "I don't fight fair, baby. I fight to win." 
 "And not one of them looked like you look when I slide inside you, every fucking time I slide inside you. Like a piece of you has been lost and now it's found." 
 Ally and Ren are TOTALLY hot together! And the storyline is pure Kristen Ashley, pure emotion, lots of action, some danger, a few misunderstandings, but above all, lots of strong, hot men and lots of strong, gorgeous women! All of our beloved characters make an appearance in Rock Chick Revolution and there's even a very familiar name (*cough*cough) thrown around. 
 I laughed a lot and I started crying at the introduction. The road to Ally and Ren's HEA was a bumpy one but of course it ends in pure beauty and perfection, as only KA can do: 
 "Because when I had to be a badass all day and cases got tough and I came home, or when life just sucked, or when life was awesome and going along fine, I knew this was what Ren Zano would give me. 
 Always. 
 Exactly what I needed." 
 ROCK ON!! 
 *A copy of the book was provided by the author in exchange for an honest review.*
Magnificent! Review to follow closer to release day.

Stunning, emotional book. Completely surprising read. 
 Please don't shy away from this book due to the war-time setting. Wounded is an emotional, satisfying story of two souls brought together by the harsh realities of war. 
 Rania is a beautiful Iraqi woman who had to resort to prostitution at a very young age in order to simply survive. She is shut down emotionally until by chance she meets Hunter, an American fighting in Iraq. They cannot communicate at first due to the language barrier but learn to communicate in other ways. 
 "He is asleep. So handsome. I do not understand what is happening to me. From the first moment I saw him, something in him called to my blood and made it sing." - Rania 
 Ms. Wilder delivers some very lush and explicit sex scenes between Rania and Hunter which were an unexpected surprise. 
 "Rania. Her name is music. Her eyes are veiled pools of expression. She hides behind anger, behind toughness. It's all an act. I see the pain. See the fear. See the need. She's lonely. She hates what she does. " - Hunter 
 The author is a gifted writer with a a sensitive voice. Wounded is not filled with light-hearted scenes, but it is ultimately a story of love and understanding that will leave you fulfilled at the end.

If you want a completely suprising and enthralling read, this book is for you. Reaper's Property is a SCORCHING romance with a super hot biker named Horse. And yes, his nickname does refer to a certain part of the male anatomy! 
 We usually don't give a synopsis in our short and sweet book reviews, but just by way of background, Marie has fallen on hard times and is trying for a fresh start by moving in with her loser brother, Jeff. Through a series of incidences told through flashbacks (which we loved, by the way), Marie is taken as collateral by Horse, a member of the Reaper's Motorcycle Club. 
 There is a lot more to Horse than his bad-ass persona. We really loved how Ms. Wylde describes the inner workings of a MC. Not sure if it's all accurate but boy is it interesting! They have their own code of ethics and do not operate like the rest of the "civilian" world. This is a rough book and um, it's not exactly a traditional "romance". Who knew there was such a distinction between a "sweet butt" and an "old lady"! 
 All we can say is BRAVO to Ms. Wylde for creating one of the most memorable bad-ass alphas out there. ***fans self*** We can't wait to read more Reaper's MC! 
 Reaper's PropertyJoanna Wylde
4 1/2 D/s stars! With a suspenseful plotline!
Five stars to Sempre. Deeply felt, moving love story of loss and redemption. Carmine and Haven will fill your dreams.

A powerfully written story that will take your breath away. You will not be able to tear yourself away from the story of Sophie and Ian. The writing is flawless and the character development perfect. Unforgettable first-kiss scene! Seriously, this book needs to be made into a movie. Put this at the top of your to-read list for 2013.

Imagine my pleasant surprise when I ended up with an ARC of Walking Disaster. I was even more surprised to be immediately drawn inside the sensitive, loving and intense head of Travis "Mad Dog" Maddox. Walking Disaster contains no surprise story lines; it is the story of Beautiful Disaster told from the POV of Travis. You do not need to have read Beautiful Disaster first, but I highly recommend that you do, in order to understand some of the nuances of the story and the characters. 
 Travis is loving, he is sexy, he is kind, he is sensitive and he is very, very caring. Yes, it's true! Jamie McGuire has created a wonderful caring male character who will become the new book boyfriend to lots of fans. 
 Travis and his family lost their beloved mother at a young age. Her last words to Travis were, "One of these days you're going to fall in love, son. Don't settle for just anyone. Choose the girl that doesn't come easy; the one you have to fight for, and then never stop fighting. Never stop fighting for what you want." 
 These words serve Travis well when he meets his match in Abby "Pidge" Abernathy. 
 Travis knows immediately that Abby is very different from the endless parade of girls that he has been with. He is aware of his bad-boy reputation, but in his mind, he has always been nothing but totally honest with every girl he has ever been with: 
 "She was my opposite: innocent on the surface, and damaged deep within." 
 I was a little frustrated at Abby's stubbornness in constantly pushing Travis away, emotionally and physically, but smart and sexy-ass Travis takes his mother's advice and fights hard for Abby! 
 "I knew the second I met you that there was something about you I needed. It turns out it wasn't something about you at all. It was just you." 
 I love a book with an alternate POV, so Walking Disaster fit the bill for me. I enjoyed reading the Las Vegas and fighting scenes from Travis' POV. You will not believe what an intelligent, caring and loyal character Travis is. 
 Finally, the author also treats us to a wonderfully surprising and satisfying Epilogue that I can only hope will lead to much more Travis and Abby! 
 Walking DisasterJamie McGuire

CollideGail McHugh 
 This book has haunted me since I finished. Emily, Gavin and Dillon really got under my skin. I so wanted for Emily to leave her boyfriend Dillon and be with Gavin, with whom she felt an instant attraction the moment they met. But she felt bound to Dillon and he uses every narcissistic trick in the book to keep her. Emily's confusion over her feelings for Dillon are at first understandable - he did help her through some very tough times - but then I found myself yelling at her to leave Dillon and be with Gavin! 
 The sex scenes I this book are really really hot but I wish there had been more! I don't want to give away any spoilers but I did enjoy catching a glimpse into what a relationship with a true narcissist might be like . My heart broke a few times during this book, it was a much darker read than I originally expected. There is a doozy of a cliffhanger and I can't wait to see how this story concludes. 
 Oh and by the way, Gavin Blake is HOT and is a new favorite book boyfriend!
Stunning book. Very emotional. Full review to follow. Be prepared to stay up until 4am reading!
4 1/2 beautiful stars. Loved it. Review to follow.

Beautiful BastardChristina Lauren 
 LOVED THIS BOOK. 
 Holy hell, the sex is hot! It comes early, it comes fast and it comes HARD. Pun intended. It's interesting that some reviewers looked at this as a negative but the fact that Chloe and Bennett have sex almost at the beginning of this book is very much a part of the narrative. They then work backwards and develop their relationship and emotional connection from there. I couldn't put this book down. I might be one of the three people in the world who did not read The Office but apparently there are some major differences between the original Twilight fanfic and Beautiful Bastard. 
 I loved how Bennett and Chloe were loved and respected by everyone else but they could not seem tone be civil towards at each other. Also loved the back and forth POV's between the two characters. 
 This book is not for everyone but it is a treat worth reading. I can't wait for more of Bennett and Chloe! 
 (ARC provided courtesy of NetGalley.)

We loved his book! There is a menage and explicit BDSM involved so this story might not be for everyone. Ms. Dalton does a wonderful job of developing the the main characters Kade, Leah and Seth, and exploring the the deepening relationship between the three. There is explicit D/s scening so be warned. And the sex scenes are STEAMY. Sequel for Tony? Pretty please?

It's difficult to write a review of a book that ends one of my favorite series ever. Did I want Olivia and Caleb's story to end? Absolutely not. I have been obsessed with these characters ever since I first read The Opportunist. Was I satisfied with the conclusion? Completely! Tarryn Fisher does not give her readers hearts, flowers and rainbows, she gives flaws, secrets and twisted emotions. You have been warned. I absolutely love a male POV and Tarryn really delivers in Thief. The first two books in this series, The Opportunist and Dirty Red, are absolute must-reads before Thief, and the entire series belongs on your immediate to-read list. A perfect 5-star story.

You will yell at the characters and also shed a tear or too! We thought we despised Leah but to the author's credit, Ms. Fisher does a fabulous job of telling Leah's backstory. And she does disappoint. We do not like to give away any spoilers, but trust us when we say that you will be shocked, saddened and stunned by this book! Oh Caleb! We still love you! Can't wait for Thief!

WOW what a surprising book! Fabulous story and characters and we could NOT put this one down. These are not your usual cast of characters, they make terrible mistakes and some are filled with anger and dishonesty! We love love love Caleb. You will immediately feel the need to read Dirty Red. Trust us, things are not what they seem... We can only hope and pray for a HEA for our Caleb and Olivia.

Put this on your list of must reads ASAP. One of my top 5 of 2012. I don't write long reviews but suffice it to say I was up until 3AM finishing this book. Andrew Parrish is my new book boyfriend. Oh, and did I mention the sex is HOT? Beautiful beautiful story.
A beautiful romance! I read this in 1 day, could not stop reading until I finished Lauren and Caden's story. The sex scenes left me breathless and the story had my heart in its clutches! A must read!

4 out of 5 stars to The Stranger (Just One Night)! 
 The Stranger is very sexy and suspenseful. I read it in just one night (pun intended). I was expecting a carbon copy of Fifty Shades or Bared to You, but this book is different. The book is told from the POV of Kasie who has a fling in Las Vegas with a very handsome stranger. Circumstances later bring them together again, which leads to Kasie being torn between being a."good girl" or following her heart. 
 This book includes some very steamy sex scenes and one very hot guy, Mr Dade. I can't wait to learn more about him in the next book because this one is told from Kasie's POV and ends rather abruptly on a huge cliff-hanger. Kasie's actions might disturb some readers, because you are told from the beginning that she has a boyfriend but I felt the author did a good job of explaining Kasie's thought process. 
 Copy provided in advance of release date courtesy of Net Galley.
Review to follow

4.5 stars!! Poughkeepsie is one of my favorite books, a beautiful, romantic and yes, sometimes violent story of true love, loyalty, goodness and family. It is a must-read, and the kind of book and characters that stay with you forever. So when I heard that Debra Anastasia planned to write a second book about Beckett Taylor, I could not wait to read it! Beckett is violent, damaged, loving, loyal and sexy -- in short, my favorite kind of (anti) hero. Beckett is in love with the equally-damaged Eve and Return to Poughkeepsie is their story. 
 Beckett is admittedly "the scariest motherfucker in Poughkeespie." He makes a decision early in this book that breaks the hearts of all those who love him. Eve is the love of his life, and um, they have some incredible chemistry: 
 "You're mine now. You gave up. Know that you could have killed me. Now nothing will stop me." 
 Despite their love for each other, Beckett feels that he must redeem himself as a person and become a man worthy of Eve and his family's love. No real spoilers here but the author then takes us on a wild ride for the rest of the story, filled with incredibly memorable characters (hello, handsome cop!), very twisted criminals and tender and heartbreaking family scenes. My loves Blake and Livia are prominent in this book as are Cole and Kyle. But the focus of the story is on Beckett and his love, Eve. 
 Eve is one kick-ass heroine and she really holds her own throughout this story. Although I absolutely loved her scenes with Beckett, I also really loved Ryan, the very sexy Poughkeepsie cop who, in another lifetime, could have been someone Eve fell for. (Could there be a spin-off here? Hmmm, let's hope so!) Eve becomes involved in a very complicated crime scheme that ultimately involves the entire clan and leads to some real nail-biting scenes. I was really rooting for Beckett and Eve and was thrilled at the conclusion to their story. 
 Although Beckett has changed somewhat in this book from Book #1, he is still the same loyal, tough, mean and sexy SOB as he was in Poughkeepsie. But it's his scenes with Eve that I loved most. 
 "Eve was magnificent. Every damn time." 
 Return to Poughkeepsie is a very substantial book, filled with sexy, funny, tender and dramatic moments. There are some heartbreaking story lines and some incredibly sexy and violent ones, too. I absolutely savored every single word of this story and was saddened to see it end. A fantastic sequel to one of my all-time favorite books. 
 (ARC provided by the author in return for an honest review.)

Beautiful story of love and redemption, with a feisty heroine and one hot hero. Do not miss reading this one. 
 "Just breathe," my mom would say. 
 "Ten tiny breaths ... 
 Seize them. 
 Feel them. 
 Love them." 
 A beautiful, beautiful book about tragedy, life, love and forgiveness. Kacey has been through a terrible tragedy and flees with her little sister, Livie, to Miami to begin a new life. Kacey has sacrificed her own dreams of college to take care of her younger sister and put her through high school. They move into an apartment complex with a cast of characters including wonderful new friends and one gorgeous neighbor, Trent Emerson. 
 Kacey tries to numb her emotions and tries to push everyone away who cares about her. I absolutely loved how this story unfolded and I. found myself really rooting for Kacey to overcome her past tragedy and. let her emotions in! There is FANTASTIC chemistry between Kacey and Trent. I also loved the other characters, especially Kacey's little 
 sister Livie. A wonderfully written book that does not disappoint. 
 .Ten Tiny BreathsK.A. Tucker

Amazing story. Wow. This is a must-read. One of the best books I have read this year, and I have read over 120. The story will amaze you, sadden you, surprise you, thrill you, and ultimately, uplift you. Enjoy! I love Sky and Holder! 
 5 stars for #Hopeless. Dean Holder & Sky will capture your heart and leave you breathless. Best First Kiss scene, ever. A must-read.

OH MY GOD! Ms. Romig has done it again. This can't really be categorized as a "romance" although sorry, again I think I might be the only reader who loved Tony! What a phenomenal story. We don't like to give a synopsis but this book picks up where Consequences left off, and we were up until the middle of night many nights reading this book. Ms. Romig has created very, very memorable characters and they will stay in your head long after you finish this book. We cannot wait until Convicted is finished! Gah! I don't want Claire and Tony's story to end! This book is a must-read.

I was thrilled to be able to read this super sexy continuation of Rebecca Mason's journey with her Master. Rebecca will belong completely to her new Master, once she signs the contract he has given her which sets the terms of their Master/sub relationship. Will Rebecca give him her ultimate trust? In this steamy novella, her Master consumes her, body and soul, even as he explores her limits: 
 "...I will push you to your limit, Rebecca, but I will always leave you thoroughly pleasured." 
 Rebecca tries not to lose herself, but she is intoxicated by her Master. He is sexy, irresistible and powerful, and I wanted to read more about him. Who is he? What happened to Rebecca? There is a hint here as to her Master's identity, and these journals are must-reads for fans of the Inside Out series. Plus, you get a sneak peek into Being Me! 
 (ARC provided by the author in exchange for an honest review.)

WHAT HAPPENED TO REBECCA? 
 I know its odd to give 5 stars to what is essentially a novella, but this to me is an essential part of the Inside Out series, of which If I Were You is one of our all-time favorite books! This is the second installment of entries from Rebecca's lost journals. Rebecca is presented with with a contract to be a submissive that she doesn't want to sign. There are subtle hints as to who the would-be Master might be. 
 This is a very short but very, very satisfying read. Can't wait for the next installment of Rebecca's lost journals. 
 (ARC provided by the author in exchange for an honest review.) 
 Rebecca's Lost Journals, Volume 2: The ContractLisa Renee Jones

We were lucky enough to get a sneak peak at volume one of Rebecca's Lost Journals: The Seduction, out on January 28th, which Lisa Renee Jones is writing to accompany her Inside Out Trilogy. 
 Rebecca's Lost Journals: The Seduction is basically the prequel to If I Were You, Book 1 of the Inside Out Trilogy. You MUST read If I Were You in case you missed it. It is in our Top 10 Books of 2012. it is the story of Sara who finds and reads the secret journals of Rebecca who has left them abandoned in an auctioned off storage unit. Very hot and sexy book with very engrossing characters and an OMG cliff hanger. 
 If you have not yet read If I Were You, START IMMEDIATELY! it is a 5 star read! 
 Rebecca's Lost Journals, Volume One: The Seduction, is fabulously engrossing, sexy and suspenseful. The only problem: I need more Mark and Chris! Read Rebecca's Journals. You will not be disappointed.

Can we give this book 6 stars? 
 We actually read this book at slower than usual because we did NOT want it to end! 
 Cathy: I loved this book! I absolutely love that Jesse is obsessive and controlling with Ava but still very, very loving. I didn't get much sleep because I couldn't stop reading. I also loved that it picked up shortly after This Man so it flowed perfectly. This book took you to another level of Jesse and Ava's relationship. 
 I don't want to give away any spoilers but one of my favorite parts of the book is when Jesse tells Ava SHE is the one who holds the power. **Swoon** 
 Ellen: I love how Ava constantly pushed Jesse. And the scene near the end of the book when she was trying to make her point to Jesse... OMG! She is in love with Jesse but she feels very insecure. 
 Jodi Ellen Malpas has written a sexy, shocking and surprising book! 
 We don't want to give away any spoilers and we assume everyone has read This Man. Beneath This Man picks up a few days after This Man ends. This book is is VERY hot and the sex scenes are AMAZING. Much of the tension in the story revolves around an anniversary party for the Manor that Ava does not want to attend. There are a LOT of surprises and the end does not disappoint! Oh and there is one really spiteful character named Sarah! Jesse, fire her! 
 You will fall in love with Jesse Ward. We can't wait for the third book, This Man Confessed. 
 "My work here is done." 
 Beneath This ManJodi Ellen Malpas

The story is GREAT. A roller coaster of a read. I think I was one of the few readers who actually loved Tony! These characters will haunt you. Especially if you stay up until 2:00 AM reading this book! Amazing debut by Aleatha Romig. I had to join the Goodreads Support Group after finishing this book! Seriously, read this book. You will not be disappointed. One of my top 10 for 2012.

I am simply speechless. One of the best books I've ever read. Where did Katja Millay go? She needs to write another book! A moving story about second chances and the power of unconditional love. TSoT should be read by everyone. 
 True story: Several years ago I was planning my attendance at my very first book signing ever. A lovely reader from SLOVENIA (yes, you read that correctly) messaged me and asked if I could please try and get a copy of TSoT signed for her by Katja Millay. Of course, I said, I would certainly try. I thought to myself. wow, this book must really be something special! And so I bought the book and there it sat on my Kindle since 2013. Yes, I met the author, she was absolutely lovely but I did not fangirl over her because I had not yet read this treasure of a book!!! And now she seems to have disappeared!! GAAHHHHHH!! I need a do-0ver!! 
 If you are like me, you probably have tons of books sitting on your e-reader (and maybe even on your bookshelf) unread for whatever reason. I made a resolution that this year, I would slow down on taking ARC's and get through all of the wonderful books that I have been meaning to get to for years. Well, TSoT is now one of my all-time favorite books. I can't stop thinking about it. The author has a special gift with the written word and I just want to shout from the rooftops about this treasure! 
 "My name is Nastya Kashnikov. I was a piano-playing prodigy who doesn't belong anywhere near an Intro to Music class. I was murdered two and a half years ago. Discuss." 
 Nastya is starting high school at a new school, where she looks and feels and acts like the outsider that she is. She pushes everyone away with her special brand of toughness AND she also refuses to speak. At all. What happened to this girl that has made her so withdrawn from her family and everyone around her? 
 "I live in a world without magic or miracles. A place where there are no clairvoyants or shapeshifters, no angels or superhuman boys to save you. A place where people die and music disintegrates and things suck." 
 Besides getting the feel and all the angst of high school EXACTLY right, the author slowly reveals what has made Nastya into the girl she is today. But if Nastya thinks she has the self-pity market cornered, she's got nothing on Josh Bennett, another loner who has had the most terrible tragedies happen to him. Josh is also unapproachable but he becomes fascinated by this girl who wears all-black every single day and acts angry all the time. 
 "She does look like a badass. I've seen her arms, and she's ripped, which is kind of weird and scary all at once because it just seems all wrong on her. She's really small and fragile-looking, and at the same time, it's like she's some exotic teenage mercenary, all rock solid, dressed in black, ready to take somebody down. None of it makes any sense. It's kind of disconcerting. She's like an optical illusion. You look at it from one angle and you see the picture and you think you've got a lock on it and then it shifts and the image changes to something entirely different and you can't even find the original picture anymore. It's a serious mindfuck." 
 Nastya is an enigma. Her story gradually begins to unfold and it is extremely unsettling and almost unbearable. For all of her toughness, she is extremely fragile and vulnerable but eventually begins to let others in. Just a little. 
 "I haven't said a word to another living person in 452 days. I write my three and a half pages, tuck away my composition book, and crawl into bed, knowing how close I came to not making it to 453." 
 Let me just say two words about this book: Josh Bennett. He is sensitive, intelligent and loyal. He realizes how fragile Nastya is. I adore him! He doesn't know why she is so closed off to the world but he very carefully begins to crack her shell, little by little. 
 "But the more she gives me, the more abstract she gets. It's like pieces to three different puzzles. You try to put them together but they never fit, and when you force them, the picture comes out all wrong. 
 Despite her resolution never to let someone love her, Nastya begins to get close to Josh and his very small circle of old friends. Their relationship unfolds very slowly but they just seem to understand each other. She still keeps secrets from him but she begins to trust him absolutely. 
 "Josh Bennett laughs, and for one minute, everything is right in the world." 
 Josh is Nastya's lifeline. As her carefully constructed world begins to fall apart, Josh is there for her. Until she pushes him away. I honestly did not know whether or not the author was going to give these two the happy ending they both so desperately deserved, but the ending was PERFECT. I almost stopped breathing during the last 15% of this book. Nastya is so pessimistic about her future that nothing about this book would have surprised me. 
 "People like Josh Bennett and I don't get perfect. Most of the time, we don't even get remotely tolerable. And that's why it scares me. Because, even if there was such a thing to begin with, perfect never lasts." 
 This book actually has some light moments and very funny scenes mixed in with all the angst. They were a welcome relief from the heaviness and were done just right. All of the supporting characters were absolutely perfect and I pray for another book soon from Katya Millay. If you haven't read this book yet, don't wait. It is truly a treasure. 
 "Every day you save me."
Read. This. Book.

Holy hell. What a ride. My heart was ripped out a couple of times during this book. Madeline Sheehan has left me absolutely speechless. I will post a review after I think about this book for a while. A must-read!!

** spoiler alert ** 
 6 Stars. 10 Stars for the sex. 
 Here is the synopsis for Grounded, Book 3 in the Up In The Air Trilogy: 
 "James and Bianca's story draws to a close in the conclusion to the Up 
 In The Air Trilogy. 
 After a short but burning hot courtship, Bianca can no longer deny her 
 feelings for James, and though she's tried her hardest, she can't help 
 but see that he cares deeply for her, as well. In an uncharacteristic 
 move, because of her abusive background, she has put aside her 
 misgivings and agrees to live with billionaire James. Is her leap of 
 faith the beginning of something wonderful, or is it too much, too 
 fast? 
 As James and Bianca feel a growing need for each other that neither 
 can deny, circumstances beyond their control intervene, trying to tear 
 them apart. Amidst the ever mounting threat of a monster who wants 
 Bianca dead, and the constant pitfalls of an indiscreet past that 
 James can't seem to escape, can these two passionate lovers manage to 
 find their happily ever after?" 
 MR. CAVENDISH. YES, PLEASE. 
 Well, we had to think about this book for a few days before writing a 
 review. This is one of those rare books that we want to give 6 stars 
 to. The writing is so rich, so descriptive, that you will not want the 
 story of James and Bianca to end. The sex scenes are GRAPHIC, they 
 are HOT and they are FREQUENT! Our kind of book, for sure! 
 You will be excited, you will be crying (sobbing!), you will be angry 
 and you will be surprised by Grounded. And there are some fabulous 
 characters that look like they might be getting their own story? 
 Hello, Ms. Lilley? We are TOTALLY excited by that! 
 Loved the settings that switch between Las Vegas and New York City, 
 the flight attendant plot device totally works for us. 
 Some of our favorite quotes (and there were a LOT!): 
 "'Turn around and look at me,' James said after a long moment, his 
 voice low and rough. It was insane, it was unreasonable, it was 
 self-destructive...and masochistic, but I grew wet at the sound of that 
 violent-roughened voice. I turned around." - Bianca 
 "Have I told you today how happy you make me? I can never go back from 
 this, Bianca. It would break me to let you go. You know that, right?" 
 - James 
 Most of our favorite quotes give away the plot so we don't want to 
 spoil the book for those that have not yet read this gem. GO READ THIS 
 BOOK NOW. You will fall in love with James.GroundedR.K. Lilley

6 stars!! I'm DEAD. Full review to come after Release Day, May 14th. Eyes Wide OpenRaine Miller

"Break Her" is one of those books that I am really not qualified to "review" because the writing is so amazing (Clue #1 as to the author's identity!) so I'll just stick to giving my humble opinion. 
 I read this book a few months ago and have been thinking about it ever since. To me, that is the hallmark of an excellent book. Here is the synopsis of the story, in which a woman wakes to find a dangerous stranger in her bed: 
 "Now your home has become your prison, and your body, a battlefield. How would you hold onto your sanity, your self-esteem, your very soul against someone determined to annihilate all three? 
 In the psychological thriller Break Her, one woman will find herself in this almost unthinkable situation, and one man will discover that he has finally come up against someone unlike any of those he has destroyed before. 
 On the surface, this intruder has all the advantages: strength, weapons, ruthlessness. The only way he can lose is if he finds himself responding to his victim on a human level. The only way she can win is if she rips away the protective lies she's told herself, the hard shell of indifference she's hidden in, and becomes again what she has not been since she lost everything that mattered to her, years ago. " 
 Break Her is a very graphic story of the gripping psychological interplay between the woman and the rapist. (I refuse to call her simply "Victim" as some reviewers have done.) The rapist is very cunning and very strong. He is determined to destroy the woman not only physically, but emotionally as well. 
 "He was decent looking. He probably had money. He could have sex any way he wanted any time he wanted. But he liked it this way." 
 The story itself is set over a period of an excruciating day and a half, within the physical confines of a house. The characters are not named by the author. Through a series of flashbacks, however, the woman's past is explained in detail and other characters are introduced. I was hanging on every word, and reading furiously to reach the stunning conclusion of this book. 
 "You think you'll wear me out," he hissed, not using a question. "You think you'll eventually satisfy me, and reach the end of this. But everything you do makes me want you more, deeper, impossibly more. I think I'm reaching a point I've never hit before. Like perpetual motion. Or nirvana. I'll never stop." 
 There are many questions raised by this story. What was the author trying to convey here? Well, first and foremost, I think it is a story of the woman's fierce strength and will to survive. The author has written this book under a pseudonym so that we do not know the writer's gender. Brilliant. 
 The author has ventured an opinion on the subject of rape in other forums that forgiveness allows rape victims to move on, and to separate themselves from what happened. The author has also questioned why rape is the only crime that seems to be an "open wound", which gives men a huge amount of power to know that by this one act, they can potentially destroy a woman. Certainly the woman in "Break Her" does not accept the definition of rape as an "open wound" and in that sense, this book is very empowering. 
 "Break Her" is an incredibly gripping and yes, emotionally exhausting, story. It is very thought-provoking and will make you question what values you believe in. I could not put this book down. I can only hope that the author chooses to continue the woman's story because I need more of this story.Break HerB.G. Harlen

Destroyed 
 By: Pepper Winters (Goodreads Author) 
 ***** 5 Killing Stars***** 
 Give me a second to fully digest everything I just read....umm... WOW ... there are no words to describe how this book made me feel. The tragic story of Roan "Fox" was simply the most heartbreaking thing ever. So when reading this book, make sure to prepare your hear, grab a box of tissues and be prepared to cry your eyes out. 
 "The moment I set eyes on her, I tasted a delicious combination of fear and strength. Weakness and bravery, sadness and resignation. Instincts and needs that I'd buried and ignored volcanoes to the surface. I lost control. I broke every rule and I didn't give a fuck. She woke a part of me I didn't know existed, layered in ice and cold blooded disassociation." 
 Roan "Fox is a tortured soul who has lived a horrible life at the hands of the worse kind of people, who kidnapped and held him captive since he was six years old. He was beaten and tortured into conditioning to doing everything and anything they wanted including kill. 
 " No one would look at me and think I was slave. But I had been. I still was. I probably would be forever." 
 Once he finally escapes he begins to live as a zombie version of himself, unable to touch or be touch, unable to please or be pleased, simply miserable, living a life void of emotions and filled with fear. That is until he meets Hazel Hunter and his miserable life changes forever. 
 "I'll give you two hundred thousand for one month of pure access. I want to buy your obedience, your body, your mind. But most of all I want to buy your secrets." 
 " Tonight, I did the one thing that made least sense of all. I bought a girl. And I would never let her go." 
 "Top rule. Unbreakable rule. Don't. Ever. Touch. Me." 
 He begins to fight all his conditioning instincts to be a "normal" man for her. But as with everything in his life, nothing is ever that easy. The road to normalcy is not as easy as he thought it would be after only one look into Zel's eyes at his club. 
 " You're Mine, and I refuse to live without you." 
 The battle with his own personal demons wasn't so easily won. He has to challenge himself again and again with fear of losing the only people he loves. 
 "Obey or I'll kill you." 
 "I'm here for you, for her. Forever if you'll have me. Just please-forgive me." 
 Hazel "Zel" is a strong courageous woman, who fights with teeth and nail to save those she loves most. She instantly feels the connection between her and Fox and gives up herself in order to try to help him find his cure to his conditioning without losing her life along the way. But her secret can kill them both... 
 " No, I'm not okay. Everything about you tells me to run, yet I ignore myself and end up getting hurt again. I find myself needing to help others-it's a compulsion driving me insane." 
 " You mistreat me, and I'll make you dickless for the rest of your life. Treat me with respect and desire and I'll stay. I accept your offer Obsidian Fox. Don't make me regret it." 
 " With fear and stupidity, I sold myself to him. Sold myself to a fighter who could sense my lies as easily as a fox senses a rabbit. 
 I regretted it. I reveled in it. It destroyed me." 
 Meanwhile she is also trying to save the life of the one person she loves most and she is afraid that in the end she will end losing them both. The life of her daughter, the life of the one person who has the ability to change everything. 
 "A child was my cure. The daughter of the woman I tried to kill. It was time to face my past full of darkness and say fuck you. It was time to start new memories." 
 "Her touch shattered me. Her touch awoke me. Her touch destroyed me." 
 Their love is like no other, together they fight every instinct in their body, to run, to harm, to kill. He doesn't think he has what it takes to be a good man for her, and she can't give up on him, It's a love that fights all battles and has the ability to destroy them both. 
 " You are worthy. Every day I spend with you, your improving." 
 "Only because I keep my distance and don't touch you. Believe me, if you knew my thoughts you would run." 
 "Do you want me to run?" 
 "You should." 
 "You own me, body and soul, Hazel Hunter. You're not just my lover but also my handler and I will walk over blades for you. I will kill for you. I will lay down my life for you." 
 So, with nothing left to say other than YOU MUST READ this book!! You will Love Fox, you will also hate him but don't let that scare you in the end he makes it worth the wait but you need to read it to find out.

****4 Intense Stars 
 There are no words to describe what I feel after reading this book! I am absolutely speechless... 
 I mean Seriously??? I don't normally drink but after all that I think I just may need one or 5! 
 There has to be another book! 
 Ok so I spent a big part of the book in a love, hate relationship with Twitch and Lexi. It's rare you read about a <"hero" like Twitch, and that makes him all that more interesting. 
 "There's something about Twitch. He's just raw." 
 He is just all kinds of twisted, but at the same time he had his sweet, and happy moments with Lexi. These two together are just a complete loving mess. 
 "Don't feel sorry for me. And don't assume you know me. You don't know shit about me." 
 The story begins when we meet 6 year old Alexa, trying to take care of a beat up 8 year old Antonio. She feels sorry for him and tries to help him as best as she can. But what she doesn't realize is that little act of kindness, changed both of their lives forever. 
 "You're hurt." 
 "No one else cares if I'm hurt." 
 I whisper, "I do." 
 We stand there, staring at each other a long time. Finally, he comes closer to me and asks, "What's your name?" 
 "Alexa. Alexa Ballentine." He nods but says nothing. 
 Finally he comes closer to me and asks, "What's your name?" 
 "Doesn't matter. You'll forget it once I'm gone." 
 Stepping closer, I promise, " No, I won't." 
 Lifting his head, he runs a hand through his messy brown hair to keep it out of his face. He watches me a second more before he utters, "Antonio Falco." 
 As I read this book several parts of if made me contemplate putting it down and moving on to another book less... RAW... But that's just the thing though, the story of Twitch and Lexi was just so intense and captivating that I had to keep reading and had to know if they did get their HEA. 
 "Monsters don't always lurk in the shadows. Sometimes they hide in plain sight." 
 "I don't want a knight in shining armor. 
 I don't want a knight in scuffed armor. 
 I want his helmet to have dents. I want my knight to be real, and dark and savage. I want my knight to be a survivor. Someone who's been tested and got through his trails. Not some pussy in gleaming metal." 
 So yes listen to the author's note, This is not a love story. This is a story of love gone wrong. So if you can't handle reading a book that will strip you bare with every dark, twisted, compelling, heart wrenching page. 
 "You'll be forever unsatisfied. No one will ever take care of you the way I can. The way I know you want it. I know what you need, Lexi, even if you don't know it yourself. But I'll teach you." 
 I won't give much of the story away because reading it all for yourself is an experience you don't want to miss, so I don't want to ruin it for you. I'll just leave you with this... If you want a crazy complicated, heart stopping, soul wrenching story then you this is a MUST READ for you!

 "Sir, you are no gentleman."

 "What man can quote a scene from the 1939 film classic? That does not happen in real life, hell, it doesn't even happen in books. I halted hastily in the middle of the parking lot. Of course--it was obvious as a hooker at a debutant ball--Hunter. Was. Gay. It explained his extraordinary looks, for no straight man looks that good--it's God's joke at women's expense. It explained his dislike of women, at least this woman. It explained his willingness to sit and listen to emotive music and contemplate the lyrical significance. Most importantly, it was the only plausible explanation for him quoting Rhett Butler, the dashing yet scandalous civil war hero from the gold standard of chick-flicks." 
 and then nothing... 
 Don't get me wrong the author had a great story, the characters were lovable and fun but there was just something, some connection missing. 
 I must say I loved Ev though, she was simply one of a kind 
 "Was he a cyborg created to epitomize masculine perfection, testing the restraint of earthly women?" 
 "But who will bring me coffee in the mornings and breakfast treats?"

 "I'm sure you can persuade Sam to fill in for me when needed." 
 "She's physically incapable of giving me a bear hug--she can only provide tiny cub hugs." 
 So... in the end of the day this book is still a must read because everyone NEEDS their Everleigh and Hunter Fix. 
 "Do you remember my tattoo? I had it inked at the end of March. Do you remember what it means"

 Anything I can do to help you?" "Just be you, Everleigh. That's all I need."

 By: Lacey Silks (Goodreads Author) 
 **** 4 Deep Stars **** 
 One word... Cliffhanger!! Ugh, have I mentioned how much I hate cliffhanger? It's a bittersweet feeling because in a way it's good for the anticipation on what will happen next, but in this case NOT SO MUCH! Great read that may leave you blushing and wanting more... Now how can I explain my feelings about this book properly without giving too much away ??? 
 "Cross was too hot for his own good. I couldn't let his Zeus like looks and charming mouth derail my plans." 
 " Of course I liked him! Even Mother Teresa would have liked him." 
 "I don't sleep around, Allie. I'm a one-girl kind of man." 
 I think that pretty much covers it Right? Other than screaming HOT DAM!!!! 
 So to Sum up, Allie needs Tristan for her Revenge Tristan needs Allie for his Rescue, the lines get blurred and things get OH SO INTERESTING!! 
 " Hit me." I could have sworn I'd heard a slight growl in his voice. 
 "What?" 
 "It's not a request. If you want me to consider you for the job you need to pin me to the floor." 
 "You just want me on top of you." I crossed my arms at my front. 
 " Actually I want you under me, and I wont have it any other way." He grinned 
 I loved the story of Allie and Tristan, It was a mixture of the beginning of their love but also gave you an insight on one of the biggest worldwide issues we have today... SEX TRAFFICKING. Allie has to go under cover to get sold as a sex slave in order to try to save Tristan's ex from being sold. It was crazy to see the reality of sex trafficking. As much as I hated reading about what some of the women went through in the book, because I know it's a reality in our lives more than we'd like it to be, it was a good way of showing the readers what many women out there are going through. 
 "If I had a choice I wouldn't hire you. I'd keep you far away from the scum we'll be dealing with. But you're too perfect for the job. You're beautiful, smart and strong." 
 But on a lighter note... Allie and Tristan Cross were a great pair. They completed each other's every need with trust in each other from day one. The chemistry between these two simply left me fanning myself... 
 "Cocky a bit? 
 " I guess you'll have to wait and see. " 
 "You're unbelievable." 
 " I Know. And I'm glad you know it, too. " 
 "Have you always been a tease Allie? Or is it just for me? 
 "What?" 
 "You say one thing but mean something else. I can see the way your body's reacting to me." I mean come on... What can you really say to that? 
 " You look beautiful when you blush." 
 " You should get off me." I felt my muscles tense." 
 "I should, and I will, but know that I don't want to." WOW!!! 
 " You taste much better than I imagined." 
 "Imagined?" 
 "I wondered about your lips all night and couldn't sleep. Now I don't have to wonder anymore." 
 "I'm glad I satisfied your curiosity." 
 But as much as Allie tried to keep their relationship strictly professional it only worked for about 2 seconds. It was great to see the sparks between these two. Because honestly with a guy like Cross I don't really blame her! 
 " I'd tasted forbidden fruit I couldn't get enough of. And I wanted more, I needed more." 
 " Mr. Impossibly hot could not only make me swoon in bed, but also in his kitchen." 
 " You perv! We're supposed to be exercising." 
 " Believe me, my heart gets a better work out when I look at you." 
 So, Like I said I hate Cliffhangers, therefore I need more of Tristan!! Like NOW !! So keep posted for the second installment "Layers Peeled". Can't WAIT!!

 Daisy has just escaped her father's prison and Nikolai is attempting to free himself from the only life he knows, at the same time they are trying to build their first relationship.

 " The villains had a hard life. They did not know any other way forward."

 With the bad guy. 
 I wonder what this makes me."

 " I love Nick for who he is, Not what he is."

 " Every day that passes, I love Nick more and more. I don't care about his past. We will build our own future, together." 
 " We're both patient people, Nick and I. We know how to wait, there's pleasure in the waiting."

 And then there is the fact that Wes is keeping a major bomb from Kiersten (spoilers) 
 "I was keeping something epic from her, which sort of made me the villain in this tale. But damn, I wanted to be the hero."

She has a way with words that I can honestly say I have cried my eyes out in each one of her books. So with that in mind I have to say this book was a little different for me. It's a really good book, very well written and all I just didn't feel all of the emotions I am used to feeling when reading a Colleen Hoover book. Don't get me wrong I really enjoyed reading the story of Ridge and Sydney. The distinct and emotional way their love for music despite all obstacles pushed them together was amazing. There is no way to write a full review without giving too much away so I'll try my best to let the character's words speak for themselves. 
 "We try so hard to hide everything we're really feeling from those who probably need to know our true feelings the most." 
 "Sometimes in life, we need a few bad days in order to keep the good ones in perspective." 
 It was beautiful to watch the two of them grow together, not only through their struggles but also through the obstacles life has thrown at them. To see them realize there is more to life then the issues they face. 
 "A life of mediocrity is a waste of a life." 
 "Words can sometimes have a far greater effect on a heart than a kiss." 
 Music is what brings them together; it's what brings light to the great connection they share. Writing music together connects the two of them in a way they never thought possible to have with another. 
 "However, I've learned that the heart can't be told when and who and how it should love. The heart does whatever the hell it wants to do. The only thing we can control is whether we give our lives and our minds the chance to catch up to our hearts." 
 These challenges and the enormity of the connection they share lead them to doing things they never thought they would be capable of. 
 "I kiss her every way I can possibly kiss her, because I plan on loving her every way I can possibly love her. Every single time we refused to cave in to our feelings in the past makes this kiss completely worth the sacrifices." 
 "The more I open up to him, the more I need him. The more I admit to myself that I need him, the most it hurts to know that I still don't exactly have him." 
 I am not going to lie, There were several times that I just wanted to shake Sydney and Ridge and tell them to just make up their mind already but then there was the soft side of me that can understand their struggle. 
 "There's no other way to describe how I feel. I know that the way I think about her and feel about her is wrong, but I struggle so much with how right it feels when I'm with her." See what I Mean??? 
 "Never in all my life and in all my years of living in a world of silence have I wanted to hear something as much as I want to hear her sing right now. I want to hear her so bad it physically hurts." 
 I mean seriously??? How can your heart not hurt for these two after Ridge saying something like that? Getting to know Ridge and the difficulties he has gone through opened my eyes to what it would be like to go through the same things. It's crazy to see that it is a reality and what sometimes can tare someone apart can also bring others together. 
 "God, if just holding hands with him feels this intense, I can't imagine what everything else with him would feel like." 
 "I don't know when you'll be ready for me. It might be next month or next year. Whenever it is, just know that I have absolutely no doubt that we can make this work. I know we can. If there are two people in this world capable of finding a way to love each other, it's us." So pretty much READ this book, like right now! You will LOVE it trust me!! 
 www.jenreadit.com
What an adorable read!!! (Review Coming Soon)
LOVED IT!!!!!

AWESOME READ!!! 
 FULL REVIEW TO COME

This book was absolutely ADORABLE!!!!!!!!!!! It was an awesome, light and FUN read. 
 I loved the characters but I absolutely LOVED Cam!!!!!!!!!!!! Major Swoooon Worthy! J 
 "You've been checking me out, haven't you? In-between your flaming insults? I feel like man candy." 
 Seriously, between being HOT, FUNNY and OH SO VERY ADORABLE, Cam was the perfect catch!! 
 " I'm not going out with you Cam." 
 " I didn't ask you at this moment, now did I" One side of his lips curved up. " But you will eventually." 
 "You're delusional" 
 "I'm determined." 
 " More like annoying." 
 " Most would say amazing." 
 Cam and Avery's relationship is tough due to the secrets she keeps but he is the perfect match for breaking her out of her shell and facing her fears. 
 This book is definitely a MUST READ. 
 Trust me when I say this YOU will not regret it! 
 www.Jenreadit.com
AWESOME READ!!! I loved to story of Aiden and Emma. It was a little predictable but in a very fun, easy read sort of way. can't wait to start reading the proposal!!
Another awesome KA read! I just can't seem to get enough!! I wish the book was longer because I wanted more of Hop and Lanie. :)
ABSOLUTELY AMAZING IN A WAY ONLY KA CAN!! Full Review to come!!
Absolutely loved it!!!!!! Hello O lol .... Priceless ;)

Simply AMAZING!!!!!!!!!!!!! 
 Once again Colleen Hoover's love stories leave me speechless and emotional. AWESOME READ!

two words... Absolutely Adorable!!!! 
 The love story of Hunter and Taylor was very entertaining and a great read.Simply an awesome Read!!

Kristen did it again! The story of Frankie and Benny was just simply absolutely AMAZING!!! I could not put it down, so much so when finished I picked up the other burg books and started re-reading it to remember all the burg history. So if you haven't yet read it be sure to do sooo !!!!

I Must say that I absolutely LOVED reading this book. It was absolutely HILARIOUS!!! I would definitely recommend it. I loved the story and the characters but I most definitely LOVED Gavin, funniest little boy ever. I must Warn you though, Do not read this in public or you will take the chance of people thinking your completely crazy for laughing out loud by yourself (True story). Once I started reading this book I was unable to put it down, and I could not stop laughing. I look forward to reading any other book Tara Sivec writes, because reading Seduction and Snacks definitely made my day.

Ok soooo I was absolutely thrilled and so incredibly sad to read this book! Trilled because I LOVED and MISSED the Rock Chicks and Hot Bunch, but Extremely sad to see the series end. Review to come...

I must say that so far I loved all of Kriten's books but I REALLY Enjoyed reading the story of Chase & Faye!! It was the perfect ending for Chace. I loved watching Faye and Chace's relationship blossom and become what they both dreamed it would. It was very cute that they both had been in love with each other for years and they finally got what they wanted. I would definitely recommend this book, once I started reading it I could barely put it down... so it's THAT good!

I have to say that I absolutely loved this book! Once I started reading it, I could not put it down! It was very entertaining to read. I loved the characters; they were crazy and fun but very enjoyable to read about. I laughed out loud throughout the entire book and loved every minute of it. I primarily liked Michael and Grace's relationship but all the others were very entertaining as well. I would definitely recommend this book to anyone who is looking for a fun read. It's definitely a MUST READ!!! I would love to read more books like it.

Death as an issue is not what one expects to find in young adult fiction. It is central to this coming-of-age story and adroitly handled. Accompanying this central issue are the expected themes: sexual awakening, conflicts with parents, identity issues, choices to be made. 
 Early in the book we see Donna, the narrator whose father has recently died, deciding to become a mortician. We follow her thinking on this as she navigates the world of senior year at high school. 
 The ending, though predictable to adults, may not be predictable to the intended audience. And although I expected the resolutions, my interest was held to see how they would be effected. And for once, changes in the characters' attitudes were adequately motivated and believable.

I had to keep reminding myself it was written in the 1950s, ten years before Stonewall. There was not much to locate it in time. I haven't decided if that is good--ie, makes it universal, or bad--missing its grounding in history. 
 It was an intense study of the self-hatred promoted by the homophobia of the times and its disastrous effects of partners, both male and female. There were stereotypical characters, but the two main ones were well developed. 
 It was a page turner, starting with something like this: tonight is the last night before the worst morning in my life. I liked the use of flashback to tell the story ( I seem to say that a lot.) The transitions of time were clear.

Written in 1988, set in the sixties when Zimbabwe was still Rhodesia, this novel follows two girls, who are cousins, in a mission school. One is the narrator, looking back at her life in the school from a more informed perspective. There is just enough of the mature commentary to remind us of the incomplete version of the younger girl. 
 The first section describes Tambu's life on the family farm while her brother goes to school and her attempt to grow enough corn and sell it to get her own school fees. The next section shows her in the mission school living with her uncle, the headmaster, rooming with her cousin, Nyasha. The third section I will leave unidentified, for it would be a giveaway. 
 In the second section as Tambu waits for her aunt, the description of the uncle's house conveys the difference between the conditions of the native population and the privileged black population. Only very indirectly do we get indications of the white population. The events that follow reveal the identity issues the two girls face. 
 I have just learned that a sequel was published in 2006 and look forward to reading it.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I enjoyed this third book almost as much as the first two. The plot had as many twists and turns and dangers, mostly overcome. I was not too surprised that Coin turned out to be a power grabber, and liked the way she was dispatched with. 
 I liked the way the author avoided killing off either Gale or Peeta; however, I felt the way she dispensed with Gale was lame. First his observation that Katniss only loved him when he was injured or needy and second his observation that the only thing he had had going was protecting her family. These did not ring true. And to blame him for Prim's death because it may have been a weapon that he created also seemed a stretch. Their hunting times had given them a much deeper bond than that. 
 Having the media people around almost all the time intensified the commentary on reality TV, and having the two versions of news underlined the importance of knowledge in making decisions and of the press. The three books together seem an indirect commentary on war video games that prepare for real war and the victors recognized the Hunger Games in the way the Capitol was booby trapped and even named the revolution Hunger Games 76. 
 I was surprised at Katniss voting for Hunger Games with the children of the decision makers of the Capitol. I could see the revenge aspect. I could see avoiding total depletion of population. But it didn't seem in character for how much she had hated the games or for her moments of realizing that people in the capitol were people too. So I am on the fence on that issue. 
 11/30/15 On rereading after the movie. I see Katniss's vote as strategy toward her new goal of killing President Coin rather than as a character inconsistency. I see an intensification of the critique of the gamelike quality of the war in looking at contemporary drone warfare. 
 Perhaps Katniss's thought, expressed only once, makes enough sense to justify her shift from Gale to Peeta: She didn't need Gale's anger; she had enough of her own. She needed Peeta's attitude for balance. She probably could have ended up happy with either. Whenever objecting to Gale's attitudes and strategies, she balanced it with thoughts of her own actions that caused deaths of others, thoughts made all the more important in these days of drone strikes and "collateral damage." Not enough that Prim is killed trying to attend the wounded, there is also the tragic irony that Katniss became a tribute in order to save her in the beginning, and the book ends with her death. 
 I see WWII connections I had missed in the last parachute attack being unnecessary because Snow was ready to surrender. [I'd not believed him on the first read, but came closer to believing him on the second, though the ambiguity is pretty strong.] Also the double attack after medical aid has come in parallels Nagasaki after Hiroshima. And the "war to end all wars" comments.

I had read that it was merely a repeat of The Hunger Games, but decided to read it anyway. And I am glad I did. The revolutionary potential of Katniss' actions has been noted and promoted a new level of oversight and punishment. It read equally as well as the first one.

Quite a good read. For once an ending seemed well handled--only one small piece seemed extraneous. Some excellent character development. I had forecast a totally different ending, and mine would have worked well also, but this one was better. I find that I enjoy being right in forecasting the ending, and I also enjoy being surprised by being wrong when it is well done.

This book should have been a nonfiction book presenting the silk factories. The plot and characters seemed to exist only to illustrate an aspect of Chinese history or factory conditions or options in 1920-30s China for women. 
 I am intrigued by the hair dressing ceremony wherein women could choose to become a member of the sisterhood of silk workers, an alternative to arranged marriages. A parallel ceremony to marriage; the choice as permanent. Like secular nuns. 
 Even if the factories allowed women to escape family and marriage, even if it allowed them to send some support home, it is not a good excuse for running a sweatshop, and this factory did become/was always that--hence the strike. However, the strike was unconvincing; the results too easy. I have read about the labor movement's beginning in the US of A, and I must confess that I am now interested to learn to what extent there was a parallel movement in China, and if indeed it was that much easier than in the US. 
 There seemed an abrupt shift from isolated rural to involvement with the Japanese invasion. While it was abrupt, it may have reflected the awareness of the rural people as the fighting moved closer to them. So I have mixed feelings about the ending. There were slight hints earlier of trouble up north. The entrance of difficulties still felt sudden and intrusive. Maybe war is like that.

Some very interesting character development, an attention holding plot. Some historic information about World War II women prisoners (though the country was changed). 
 Once the main character became an entrepreneur, it became unbelievable, but still a fun read.
The plot pacing was excellent, and the book held my attention. The well-rounded character development allowed me to change my opinion of several actors.

Two things appealed to me about this book. First, I am fascinated by animals learning human language, had read about Nim Chimsky long ago and was fascinated by the use of sign language with animals. I appreciated the notes at the end leading to research backing the novel actions and to the comment that most of the ape - human conversation was based on real conversations, although the book was fiction. 
 Second, it was a real page turner with twists and turns. Some events I could figure out ahead and some surprised me, a nice balance.

After reading that the author has both Armenian and Turkish ancestors I appreciated the history of the book more. As with many novels with a historical context, it dealt with history that I am not overly familiar with. 
 I appreciated the character development most throughout this rather slowly paced novel. The aunts progressed from grotesques in the beginning to loveable characters by the end. The plot had enough twists and turns to really hold my interest. I both enjoyed and got frustrated by the alternating families and settings. The author gave clues to help keep characters' contexts straight, but not clues as to which of many in some listings to remember. I guess that is what second readings are for.

The plot a page turner. The maids reflect the Mammy stereotype. I would like to see the story written by one of the maids. I recommend Maid in the USA by Mary Romano as a corrective. It is an ethnography about real live maids along with research about labor law and how it hasn't been applied to housemaids. 
 The dialect was a sad imitation of Black Vernacular English.
A page turner. Since I hate reality TV I valued the parody of it. Some good character development.

I was a little slow in getting around to reading this one. I did start it once quite a while ago but couldn't get into it. This time I forged through the first 40 pages to finally become engaged as Offred told more of her past in contrast to her present. The movement between past and present is often quick, mere hints, but gradually they pile up into a whole.The treatment of women is an extension of attitudes as current now as when the book was written. 
 For quite a number of pages, the pace remained slow; the life restricted routine. Various liaisons later and the pace quickens. 
 For once an ending is well done. (view spoiler)[There is ambiguity whether she is taken by friend or foe at the end. Then there are the scholars' reports in the 2100s after the finding of the journal that is the novel. The ambiguity is only partially resolved. Offred made it to Maine, but there is no further trace. A parallel to the end of Offred's friend Moira. (hide spoiler)]
I was afraid it would merely be a rerun of Pillars in a new era, but it managed to add a new dimension.
Although it is long, it was hard to find a place to put it down. Some very interesting characters, especially the women.

Saleem was born at midnight at the same time as India got its independence, thus, the novel claims, the two were intertwined. There is also the claim that past generations and history are essential to understanding identity along with future events caused by actions or inactions of the person; however, this idea is undercut almost as often as it is presented. 
 On the first reading I was just confused. On the second I kept better track of the characters because I remembered most of the names that reappeared. I was also better able to keep track of India/Pakastan history and politics the second time through. 
 I laughed frequently, but most heartily at the chapter "Hit the Spittoon" and at the courtship in fragments with the sheet with the hole. Fragmentation imagery abounds in the story and in the related history. 
 Rushdie presents an interesting study of relativity. One memorable mention was this: India is a land of alternative realities and Pakastan a land of infinite falsehoods. (Not quite quoted exactly) Another is the section about the India/Pakastan war that juxtaposes the headlines from newspapers from each country. And a view of history: Saleem remembers things partially and fills in the gaps. Other events make us question his reliability as recorder. 
 I am glad I took the time to reread it, because the second reading was a valuable experience.
Darker than her other books.

The book has been around a while so I was familiar with the general themes. Still, it was interesting to read about studies and see their methods analyzed as well as getting other details to fill in the outline.

While each book stands alone, each also refers to previous books, and recognizing references adds to the pleasure. Having read some out of sequence hinders some of my suspicions because a potential suspect arises but I know s/he appears in a later book. That is not the author's fault. 
 Clara and Myrna and Ruth are major characters in this one as they were in the ones before. The focus shifts among other villager/ investigator people, though some of them seem to be steady players. The major ones continue to be well developed and interesting. And mostly likable. 
 When reading a later book and coming across a reference to "the Arnot case" I'd expected one of the earlier books to be about it. However, the first book also referred to it in the past. There was a bit of explanation in #2 and more in #3, for which I was grateful. 
 This third in the series is the best so far (after a rather odd beginning with a seance). The clues and red herrings were adroitly handled all the way to the end.

The primary thing for me in a mystery is how well the various options for solution are kept open till the end. In this book that was accomplished very well. The secondary consideration is characterization, and I am really growing to like the regulars in Penny's novels. 
 I am amused, however by what seems an inconsistency. In the later books, there is no online connectivity from Three Pines; in the earlier ones there is, albeit Slow. I was about to capitalize 'slow'; however, according to the book that would imply an acronym. As in Ruth's poetry, I'm FINE. 
 A good read.

Fun to head back to #1 after reading 3 of the more recent (one more new one yet to read). And interesting fact: I'd always assumed references to prior cases were references to prior books. However, here in the first book are references to prior cases. Either it is just part of the needed context or there will be a new novel set before this first one. Time will tell. 
 Also amusing. Here in the first one, cell phones worked in Three pines. In the later ones they don't. 
 And as far as I can tell, an inconsistency within this first one: an early scene takes place in the bistro and it is about a delay; later when that delay is explained, it also happened at the bistro, so would have been impossible for the waiting person to have missed it. Small detail. 
 One thing I enjoy about Penny'e mysteries is the characterization, and it is present in this early book. And she does well at red herring clues among the real clues.

Excellent as mysteries go. Some interesting character development. Definitely a page turner with enough false cues to keep me guessing. And reading. Quite a page turner. Occasionally it was quite confusing where I was in the chronology of the story as scenes changed. 
 It is funny to read a series backwards--and I had happened to read the next one first. Lessens the anxiety as "the plot thickens." But I think I'll go back to the beginning for the rest. 
 Nov. 2, 2016 
 Having read #1-#8, I returned to this one. I had forgotten many details already, so it was an interesting read again. Plus details had more meaning after having read the previous volumes. After the less intriguing #8, my interest in this one was much higher. Back in Three Pines, the villagers again appeared, some growing, some not. The richer plot and characterization was a relief and joy.

This is the second one I have read, and both featured art. I wonder if that is true of all. If so, I will enjoy it. 
 This one was well paced and had the right amount of twists, false leads, and turns; however, I am not convinced the ending was inevitable or the best possible. One structural thing I found a little disconcerting was the extremely short segments before switching points of view. 
 One thing I have liked about the two I have read was that character development is as important as solving the mystery. 
 I will be reading more of the series. Back references are explained enough for those of us reading out of order, but I'd guess it would be more fun if you knew the back story. it will be a different kind of reading fun to read them, knowing what story follows. 
 January 2017 
 I am reading the series in order; yes, it is more fun reading this one and knowing the various back stories. I found the short segments less distracting than on first read, maybe because I knew the outcome so was less interested in knowing what happened and what was going to happen. I also found the ending more believable, maybe because I caught more of the details along the way.
Mildly entertaining. Some interesting social attitudes and family conflicts. Conversation was not convincing as conversation. Unexpected ending.

The major spokespeople are Alma, Maribel's mother and Mayor, Maribel's friend. Others from the immigrant community get a short vignette. While the vignettes provide insight into reasons for immigrating and where it led the immigrants, they do not seem well integrated into the novel. I tried to look at the main character of the novel as the group called 'immigrants,' but I couldn't make it work. It is mostly Alma's story. 
 The plot moves well, otherwise, with events feeling inevitable, given choices made. And yes, it seemed likely that those characters would make those choices. The characters (save one or two) are quite likable and the main characters are well developed. 
 It was the Multnomah County 'Everybody Reads' book, and I look forward to the discussions it should promote.

The prose is lyrical in this memoir written to a 15 year old son. I am grateful to be able to eavesdrop on the meditations on race, on fear, on survival. It is written with the awareness that the struggle changes with the generations, but struggle it remains. The vulnerability of the black body remains. 
 "You are growing into consciousness, and my wish for you is that you feel no need to constrict yourself to make other people feel comfortable. None of that can change the math anyway. I never wanted you to be twice as good as them, so much as I have always wanted you to attack every day of your brief bright life in struggle. The people who must believe they are white can never be your measuring stick. I would not have you descend into your own dream. I would have you be a conscious citizen of this terrible and beautiful world" (107-108).

I had to look up "geek" because it surely didn't mean the detailed interest of , say, a computer geek. So I learned the carnival meaning. Luckily the really gross and bloody part occurred only briefly at the beginning. The next oddity was the father deciding to produce his own freak show for the carnival (based on his seeing horticultural variety at the International Test Rose Garden). The mother dutifully took drugs to alter her offspring. Their living children were four: Arty with fins for arms and legs; Elly and Iphy, the Siamese twins; Oly, the hunchbacked, dwarf narrator; and Chick the youngest, with his special powers. 
 Had it not been a group read, I might have stopped there. However, I remembered a comment of a professor about other novels with "grotesques": What could the author say through them that couldn't be said through more average characters? I decided to read a bit more through that frame. Then the next chapter captured my attention with its narrative strategy of jumping into the future with Oly and her daughter Miranda. Several events are revealed that make a reader wonder how they happened. That same strategy is used a few more times, like a carrot to keep one reading. For the first two thirds of the book, the pacing was very effective. Then the notes of a reporter/participant were introduced, and while they provided important information that Oly, the narrator, couldn't have known, they dragged the pace considerably. Also the very ending of the book, while motivated, seemed to take too long. It also left me wondering to what extent it was a change in her character instead of an extension. 
 I have not yet answered the What could be said question. First hypothesis, something about disability issues. Did not hold up. Second hypothesis, something about minorities. The carnival provided a sort of ghetto where deformities were normal; however, the carnival was dependent on the money of the norms buying tickets. Oly didn't feel odd till she no longer lived in the carnival setting. 
 One group member read an interview with the author and learned she is an environmentalist and is anti-war. Perhaps the father's manipulation is an extreme of the various pollutants in our atmosphere, food, and water. And there was one paragraph in the reporter's notes where Arty ponders how people could criticize his followers who are maimed by choice and not criticize war with the injuries it produces. Maybe. And is it really choice when there is cult-like power in the leader and manipulation? I feel the need to think more on the followers' willingness to endure amputation and what it might say about other things we readers may be willing to give up and for what.
Surreal. Entertaining. Far more allusions than I can recognize. Worth pondering.

Although 900 pages is overwhelming, it was a good read. 
 The first three or four chapters introduce readers to various interrelated groups of people; other characters are introduced along the way. At one point I counted 8 subplots going. More were added. 
 As you might imagine, that made for a lot of cliff hangers--but they weren't really intense till the last 150 pages. There were a few times I wanted to say, Just get on with it. But generally the pacing was effective. Time was not linear. Some background was withheld till the last 300 or so pages. There were two major sections that provided back story. There were some sections set in the future. 
 Most background bits and character sketches were relevant and interesting. More for understanding character than furthering plot, though some did move the plot along. It was fun to see a scene reappear from someone else's perspective or as background to something else going on. I am sure it happened more than I recognized. 
 Interludes likewise provided insight into characters and added to plot: a letter from father, never sent, two communications from a son/grandson. There was an article written by one of the journalist characters split into two--it provided characterization and background, and the second part moved plot. However, readers got to see characters reading it and reacting before we got to read that portion of the article. There was a fanzine published by one of the characters. Some of it was important to the plot, some was extraneous. 
 It is a book for enjoying the journey more than finding out who dunnit. 
 Most of the plots were tied up. Some resolutions I'd anticipated, some were very surprising. A good mix. I have noticed a tendency in current fiction to explain how things turn out years beyond the ending; I prefer the older suggestion/hints approach to the future.. This novel projected for a couple of characters, but it was not excessive. 
 Characters were well drawn. I can think of only one that was totally unlikable. Most were sympathetically presented, even some I'd not have liked if meeting them in real life. 
 The descriptions captured mood of the city and of the people. Some were interesting for themselves. my favorite was of the subway near the end. I'll leave you to find it.

I heard Percy at the local Wordstock day, and I was drawn to read the book by the description of bringing the Lewis and Clark expedition into the future apocalypse. Actually I think the main link to history is the naming of characters. (I googled names of those on the expedition and yes they were on the original, but not necessarily similar. For example Clark is a female ranger, though she led the book's expedition; York is her half brother, though it is indicated he is dark.) I saw two parallels: Lewis kept a journal and the two got separated for a piece. Maybe someone who knows more about the historical trek would see more subtle parallels. 
 The pacing was intense. There were always several subplots going, and moving back and forth was pretty well signaled--only occasionally confusing. The shifts created many cliff hangers. It was very hard to put down at bedtime. (And you can see I didn't put it down many times.) There were enough twists and turns, but not too many.
