I have a low tolerance for them as a rule but I thought Reid did a good job making the audience understand why Emma wavered between the two men, and none of the characters act with malice towards each other. The period of wavering also doesn't go on for too long without resolution. 
 Part of me wants to give this five stars because I did felt such a high level of emotional engagement. My heart says five stars but my head says "Jesse and Sam are a little too unrealistically mature and saintly" and "the ending, while enormously satisfying, is also overly tidy" so I'm going for 4.

Super nifty premise, sharp writing with dark and vivid imagery, a gut punch of an ending, and some moments where I said to myself "I really wish this was longer." A lot of creativity packed into a small package here. I'd love to read a full length novel rather than a novella from this author. Glad I read this.

Nothing hits the spot like a Diane Chamberlain novel when she's in the zone. I enjoyed the hell out of this. The interpersonal drama between Tess and her family and Vincent and Henry and his family was very compelling. Each character had nuanced motivations and their relationships were appropriately complicated and fascinating. There's a good amount of historical information seamlessly integrated into the story and Chamberlain does a great job establishing the local culture and mores of Little Italy, Baltimore and Hickory, North Carolina. 
 There are some twists and turns and mysteries that are resolved in a very satisfying way. Twists can fail in two very different ways. They can be so random and poorly foreshadowed that they seem contrived or super conventional and predictable and thus not very twisty. (view spoiler)[ Henry's secret mixed race love affair with a childhood friend and unacknowledged biracial children (hide spoiler)] hit the sweet spot as far as family mysteries go, not too out there or too predictable. 
 I loved this. Go read it!

A decent way to kill a few hours on a Sunday afternoon but nothing more than that. I was entertained enough to keep turning the pages but this didn't feel particularly fresh or creative and the characterizations were superficial. This is the novel equivalent of a TV movie that keeps you watching, but won't stick in your memory for any period of time. 
 I was intrigued by a premise that so directly references the well known "final girl" trope because I see a fair number of horror movies. The crime that made Quincy a "final girl" is a very boilerplate horror movie type of crime. A slasher attacks a bunch of horny teens holed up in a cabin in the woods. Flashbacks to this crime, which Quincy doesn't remember, are intercut with present day scenes of her interacting with prickly final girl Sam (view spoiler)[ who is not actually Sam but rather a former psychiatric patient named Tina who has stolen dead Sam's identity (hide spoiler)] and dealing with the death of first final girl Lisa and her superficially fine but actually underwhelming relationship with her quasi-fiance Jeff. This is doesn't have a ton of twists and turns until we get to the third act where (view spoiler)[ we find out "Sam" isn't actually Sam and Quincy's long time supportive cop buddy Coop is actually...gasp...shock....the killer all along mwahahaha (hide spoiler)] The execution of this plot is thoroughly adequate. I found enough details of Quincy's life and background, as well as the other two final girls, to keep reading even though this book adopts many cliches of the horror genre without altering or subverting them (while this book lifts plot points/characterizations from horror movies, I wouldn't consider it a horror novel at all). When the mystery plot, such as it is, does get going it works well enough in a 3 star kind of way.

This had some good scenes/moments but on the whole it's underwhelming. It's meandering and low key to the point of being stuporous. There's no plot and the characters don't really have arcs. No one here demonstrates much growth or change. Marcus isn't realistic and while he's likable enough I guess he's not especially interesting. 
 I'll struggle to recall I even read this beige book in a month. It's one of those books that evaporates from your consciousness even as you're reading. Yawn.

Feelings. So many feelings. This is tragic and funny and sweet and disturbing and moving and I am just a puddle of feelings. Eleanor is a truly magical character. Her distinctive perspective, her smartly written internal monologue, is a joy to read. There are so many clever turns of phrase and observations in this book. Eleanor is socially isolated and socially awkward, due to some pretty horrific past trauma that is revealed gradually over the course of the book. 
 At the start of the novel she seems content with a deeply solitary life defined by ritual and brisk, efficient self sufficiency. She performs her nondescript office job well, she has set pre- and post-work routines that get her through her days. She knows precisely what to eat and what to read and what to listen to and what to watch and what bus routes to take and where to shop and what crossword puzzles to do. She is highly intelligent. Yet she is alone. 
 This is no way to briefly describe Eleanor's emotional journey over the course of this book in a way that really does it justice. A short plot synopsis makes this sound like a cheesy Hallmark movie when it is so much more. It is perfectly accurate to say this is about Eleanor getting in touch with emotions that she could not let herself feel until the age of thirty. This is about a woman discovering who she is and what she wants and needs and deserves. It is about a lonely woman reaching out and finding desperately needed friendship and love from unexpected sources. Reading these last few lines, I know my summation sounds corny, but this is so well written. This book is never maudlin or contrived. It is not manipulative. It is beautiful mix of humor and heartache. Eleanor is a character whose unique experiences and personal idiosyncrasies will stay with me for a long time. 
 This is so, so, so good. I loved it

3.5 stars. This is a book about people who desire to have meaningful sexual and platonic connections with others, and their bumbling attempts to gain and maintain these connections. While this book has comedic elements, I do think the blurbs are overselling the humor. There are scenes and lines that are amusing, but it's not really laugh out loud funny. 
 Eve becomes obsessed with MILF porn after receiving an errant dirty text, and all her social encounters take on this erotic charge as she becomes more immersed in the world of online porn to combat her loneliness as a divorced woman who has just sent her only child to college. She develops an intense, complicated friendship with one of her employees, Amanda. She signs up for a gender studies course and builds relationships with her professor and several of her classmates, who form a strong roster of supporting characters even if the level of intimacy between the students and the professor was far fetched. 
 Brendan's chapters were a total drag though. He's a boring, basic, super douche bro. I don't have any criticisms in terms of the authenticity of Perrotta's portrayal, and I don't think Perrotta wants the audience to like Brendan. I think he does accurately capture the voice of a certain type of teenage boy. He's just not the type of character I care to read about. If Brendan's chapters had been written in third person, like the others, instead of first person, maybe I would have liked them more.

This is a super fast read. I didn't time myself with a stopwatch or anything but I know it took less than two hours to read cover to cover. So the time investment this slim volume requires is minimal. Given that this book demanded so little of me, I guess I can say it was well written enough to justify the short amount of time I spent reading, but it was so fragmented and slight it was frustrating as well. 
 This reads like an essay collection or a diary. It's a random grab bag of the protagonist Thandi's musings about her life. It's so episodic it feels like a stretch to even call it a novel. The narrative spine holding everything together is supposed to be Thandi's grief over the death of her mother, but even that defining tragedy isn't enough to make this feel cohesive. The chapters are all very short. Some "chapters" are merely a sentence or a paragraph, others ambitiously span two to (occasionally) three whole pages. Many of these vignettes are intimate, surveying Thandi's innermost feelings about her family, her love life, and her feelings of dislocation as she tries to understand her identity as a wealthy, light skinned black woman who is a the daughter of a South African mother. If we take each of these tiny chapters as an independent work, some of them are impressive in how much emotion they manage to convey so quickly. Others are random and disconnected from Thandi's immediate experiences and feel like things college freshmen say to each other at 3 am to show off how deep they are. The way Clemmons writes about South Africa was hit or miss for me. Thandi's personal observations about South Africa, as someone who warily visits but never really feels at home there, are interesting but the "let's talk about Oscar Pistorius and Winnie Mandela and Kevin Carter randomly for a few pages" inserts are just odd and jarring. 
 This is a three star read as is because it reads more like an outline or a rough draft of a potentially excellent book yet to be written rather than a finished work in and of itself. Thandi is just interesting enough, and Clemmons's writing is good enough to be worth the minor time investment this book requires, but I also kept thinking this could have been so much more than it was.

I love Uncle Stevie so I really gave this the old college try. I tried so hard to like it but a) the plot moves at a brutally sluggish pace and b) the way too large ensemble cast is composed of boring characters that are largely impossible to distinguish from each other.

4.5 stars. Delightfully bonkers. This is certainly a one of a kind reading experience. You're never going to say, "yawn, not another story about a woman who has to move in with her impoverished, elderly father and his sex dolls after she flees her marriage to a maniacal tech billionaire who wants to literally mind meld with her after years of monitoring and controlling her every movement within his space age compound. How cliched, another book where a subplot revolves the bumblings of a con artist who has to quit his lucrative work seducing and then stealing from women when he develops an insatiable sexual attraction to dolphins that makes him unable to perform sexually around human women." 
 This gets major creativity and cleverness points from me for its cracked out craziness. Nutting is very imaginative and twisted in a way that certainly makes for a page turning read. The futuristic tech in this novel (which is set in 2018-2019), created by Byron as the head of Gogol, feels realistic enough to be unnerving. I was also impressed by how this book managed to be quite humorous and quite dark at the same time. As wacky as this book is, Nutting is not just trading on novelty and shock value. As good science fiction tends to, this book has smart things to say about our world. 
 The dialogue is very stylized and artificial. It's snappy and fun and impressively crafted, but it doesn't resemble the way humans actually talk to each other. For the most part I was totally fine with this because truly "realistic" conversations are usually not interesting or articulate enough to be enshrined in print to be read for entertainment purposes but occasionally I was pulled out of the story by the artifice of the character's interactions with each other, or by a descriptive aside I thought was trying a bit too hard. This is really, really good, just a shade under 5 stars. I had high expectations for this having read Nutting's first novel Tampa and she delivered.
I didn't finish this but I am shocked it has such crazy good reviews. What I read was so bad. Cheesy, implausible, and with all the depth and emotional heft of a napkin. I don't get the hype at all.

This is fun. Quick gives us two mysteries for the price of one. Our protagonist "Irene" is in California working at a low rent gossip rag under an assumed name after her boss is murdered due to her possession of a rare and valuable notebook. As Irene is now in possession of this notebook, her own life is very much in danger. In her new home she is drawn into a new mystery, a drowned minor starlet who had been entangled with powerful star Nick Treymayne. Other women start turning up dead the same way, "accidentally" drowned. Irene is assisted in her investigation by the owner of the Burning Cove hotel, Oliver Ward, a former magician who was badly injured during a trick gone wrong. As tends to happen in these sorts of books, romance blooms as they try to crack this case together. 
 The suspense here doesn't really revolve around who is committing the crimes. In one of mysteries the perps are known from the outset, and in the other we do have some cool last minute twists but the search for the identity of the killer is not the most important part the narrative. So instead of a whodunit it's more of a how and whydunit. I was very pleased with how this was plotted. Quick hits that sweet spot in terms of the two mysteries. They are neither too simple nor too convoluted. Irene is a fine lead and Oliver had a really cool back story that was fun to read about in its own right. Their relationship is sweet and drama free, a nice subplot which doesn't feel contrived and doesn't overwhelm the mystery plot(s). There's a continual undercurrent of danger as Irene is being menaced not only by the murderers who want the notebook, but from studio system muscle committed to preserving Nick's reputation at all costs. 
 My only beef was that I didn't get a strong enough sense of the historical time period. I wanted to read this book in the first place because of it's Depression era Hollywood setting. There's little that happens here that feels specific to that time period, and you don't get that much historical information about the 1930's movie industry. 90% of what transpires could have occurred in 2017. So I enjoyed this a lot but for a work of historical fiction you don't get that feeling of being transported into another time which was a bit disappointing.
Cold and dull.

I didn't expect to read this whole book today but it was so brilliant I couldn't put it down. El Akkad has crafted a devastating survey of the horror of war that feels timeless and true and disturbingly plausible. Even though this is set in the future, starting in 2075 and stretching into the 22nd century, the audience doesn't get the benefit of seeing any of the events as part of a remote, alien future. 
 El Akkad chronicles the destructive power of war at the macro level and the micro level. The Second American Civil War has wrought havoc at a regional, national, and global level. Mass casualties result from drone warfare, guerrilla battles, terrorist attacks and plague. Those who survive are frequently impoverished and physically and psychically damaged. We learn about the carnage through World War Z esque historical document inserts sprinkled throughout the text. 
 Refugee camps dot the blighted landscape. The Chestnut family spend six years in one such camp. El Akkad includes enough smartly written and haunting information about the large scale destruction of the Second Civil War (I will get chills every time I hear "South Carolina" for the forseeable future), but he is also interested in chronicling with searing power the dissolution of a family and an individual as they are subjected to the vicissitudes of the conflict. Our protagonist is Sarat, who is thrust into the eye of the war when her father is murdered and she is forced into a refugee camp with her mother and two siblings. She suffers unimaginable horrors over the twenty year course of the war. (view spoiler)[ Her mother is murdered when the camp is ambushed, her brother suffers brain damage, her sister is killed by a drone, and she is subject to seven years of imprisonment based on faulty intelligence. She is finally released when the war ends and stays with her brother, sister in law and nephew but she has been so scarred by what she has experienced she decides to destroy most of the country by smuggling a deadly plague up North to be released during a war ending "reconciliation ceremony" (hide spoiler)] 
 This is expertly plotted and the prose is excellent. Individual lines leap off the page, shining with truth and power. I was totally blown away by how thoroughly I bought into El Akkad's vision, how deeply I mourned for these characters and their circumstances. The level of moral ambiguity and complexity in the story and the characterizations impressed me. Moral/ideological/political causes of the war are barely discussed because the act of war itself has stripped the principles away from north and south alike, so only simmering tribal hatred remains. This is spectacular.

This is like a Muppet Babies version of Game of Thrones. I dug it a lot. As the title suggests, four of the five main characters are bastard offspring of royalty who are on the run from murderous mercenaries and from a war their traitorous relatives are trying to start. The characters are tropes straight out of central casting but I liked their rapport and their back stories enough not to mind they weren't original. You have Jax the stable boy, Miles the stuffy book worm, Zell the taciturn warrior whose hard outer shell masks his nobility and kindness, Lyriana the crunchy, touchy feely, do gooder type, and Tilla your narrator who is struggling with insecurities borne of her lowly station. They are different enough from each other that there are opportunities for friction, but they also have the common experience of being outcasts and their shared trials to bond them together. 
 This book is quite dark. There is a lot of gore and violence, and there's plenty of pain in the character's past and present. This dark material is written powerfully and sensitively, and intercut with some understated humor that works without seeming out of place. 
 Also, I can't believe I'm typing this, but the obligatory sort of love triangle, which typically drives me bonkers in stories like this, is actually compelling. It doesn't dominate the story thankfully but what's there is good. Tilla is hot for Zell because he's brooding and tortured and hot. He reciprocates those feelings but he has very understandable intimacy issues. Miles has pined for Tilla his whole life but she's just not into him. Each character behaves in an interesting, plausible way, it ties nicely into the resolution of the plot, and Shvartz really nails the dark side of male entitlement. 
 This book isn't seeking to reinvent the wheel but Shvartz writes well enough that he can make even shop worn conventions of the genre feel interesting. I read this in one sitting and enjoyed it a lot.

My God this book is amazing. I started reading it around 11:30 tonight and of course I had to stay up most of the night to devour it in one sitting. This is one of those books that is so excellent any amount of praise I can lavish upon it, no matter how gushing, feels inadequate. This just totally knocked my socks off. 
 Evelyn Hugo is a magnificent character. Reid makes her totally authentic while also successfully communicating how this woman thrived in Hollywood for decades as a beloved, coveted megastar. The complexity of the characterization is impressive. Evelyn is such a fascinating woman, who has lead such a complicated life, and Reid has her narrate her life story with great self awareness and perceptiveness. After an introduction, the book is broken into seven parts, each named after one of Evelyn's husbands. All seven men are distinct, well developed characters who have fascinating relationships with Evelyn. Writing one compelling literary marriage is impressive, Reid writes seven with great skill. I always had a great understanding of what Evelyn saw in each of her doomed marriages, what the men saw in her, and how their marriage worked. Some of the marriages are purely transactional, others are based differing combinations of sexual attraction, platonic love, convenience, and status seeking. The level of nuance was so impressive I really felt like I lived beside these characters. One of the things this book does so well is explore how these characters conceive of what love means. 
 I have been learning a lot about Old Hollywood these last several months as I have been listening to Karina Longworth's "You Must Remember This" podcast. My husband is also incredibly knowledgeable about film history and film making, and I can't help but pick up some of his knowledge, so I feel confident in saying that I know enough to praise Reid for how accurate her portrayal of Hollywood is. As crazy and soap operatic as Evelyn's life was, with all the dizzying highs and crushing lows, she nails Evelyn's career trajectory so perfectly it's hard to believe this isn't a work of historical fiction. I can't believe Evelyn Hugo is not a real person, and that these things didn't happen. 
 Now, I don't consider this next point a spoiler because it's revealed fairly early in the text, but it's not in the goodreads plot summary so if you're very spoiler sensitive skip this sentence ---> . 
 Monique, the woman entrusted with Evelyn's story, is most curious about which of Evelyn's husbands was her true love. We find out that actually Evelyn is bisexual and that her greatest love was a female actress, a costar who transitioned quickly from rival to friend then lover named Celia. There's is the defining relationship of Evelyn's life. As passionately as they are bonded to each other, the need to conceal their relationship exerts a heavy toll. 
 I cannot recommend this book enough. I just adored it. I was moved to the point of tearing up near the end, as the cumulative emotional weight of Evelyn's life washed over me.

This is definitely a page turner, and a lot of the observational writing is sharp and astute. However, while this is definitely compelling it is also kind of irritating and it left me feeling somewhat underwhelmed when it was all over. This is the kind of book that sucks you in, demands you read on but when it's over you say to yourself, "oh, that's it." 
 I think my main beef is for a book with such a dark premise it really chickens out. Grace is a totally insufferable character. She's smug and cold and shallow and oblivious and incredibly whiny yet super, super privileged despite her constant claims to the contrary. I am fine with unsympathetic characters as long as they're interesting, which Grace is for a lot of the book, but I wanted her to really get her comeuppance in a way she never does. Frankly, she needs to suffer more to make this really pay off. She needs to suffer materially and psychologically and emotionally. She needs to be wracked with self doubt and she needs to face hostility from the outside world. This is after all a therapist who just wrote a book castigating women for not avoiding toxic men, and she married a psycho. 
 Korelitz spends a lot of time teasing the audience about the darkness that lurks in the heart of Grace's husband. She really stretches things out. I thought Korelitz did a good job writing the mounting sense of dread Grace experienced, and the actual discovery scenes are quite good. However, once the bombshells finally drop, and they are bombshells, the actual fallout doesn't match the enormity of the betrayal. I think one reason is because Grace is so rich. Her wealth insulates her from a lot of the practical consequences of her husband's betrayal. Most people can't fall back on a six figure bank account and most people can't easily just stop going to work to hide out in their lake houses when things get tough. Her child has zero adjustment issues. Everyone around her is nurturing and supportive as she deals with everything even though she's been such a pill herself throughout the whole book. She has a sweet male neighbor to act as a new love interest. Her "wrecked" life is easier and better than most people's lives. I was promised devastation. Devastation I don't get. The actual consequences for Grace should be cataclysmic and they're just not. The only thing she loses is something that has little emotional weight for the reader since Jonathan is a character who exists totally offscreen (or off-page more precisely). 
 All the set up is very good, the payoff is less so. This is a four star book and a two star book mashed together so I'll give it a three star rating.

Before I started reading this my husband told me a) I would love it and b) the threat of Greg Stillson's political ascension would be particularly disturbing to read in Trump's America. He was right on both counts. 
 I loved this book so very much. It is clever and twisty but not convoluted. The reactions to Johnny's clairvoyance feel very realistic. I am a big believer in supernatural stories that have authentic characters with reactions to supernatural phenomena that feel plausible and grounded. Johnny gets famous, he gets publicly roasted as a crank, his coma and subsequent reawakening make his mother's religious mania even more acute. His friends are compassionate but also scared of him. This book is so poignant. The reader becomes so emotionally attached to the characters so quickly. My heart really broke over the thwarted love of Johnny and Sarah. My emotions were completely engaged from page one until the end. 
 And then we get to Stillson. Even though King provides a few excellent vignettes highlighting Stillson's character early in the text, Stillson is not a major player until the third act. The specter of him percolates in the background as Johnny confronts other villainy (such as the Castle Rock strangler) and struggles to reorient himself in the world. He is a shadow lurking at the edges of this story. Stillson is an excellent villain when he finally emerges as a formidable politician and head of his own "America Now" splinter party. Try to read his comments in 2017 without a chill running down your spine. King does such a good job capturing the politicial milieu of the 1970's, yet this also feels so disturbingly relevant. A book that totally nails a specific moment in time that nonetheless feels timeless is quite special indeed. 
 This is amazing, drop whatever you're doing and read it now. Do it now!

Another strong entry in the series. These books do a really good job of relaying historical information in a fun, user friendly way and the sisters are distinctive, interesting characters. Stewart has a charming voice as an author.

3.5 stars. For the reader who is able to accept a clever yet far fetched premise and historical romance that's pretty light on history this is charming and sweet and funny. I enjoyed it. Good fluff reading. Yay lobsters. I would have enjoyed reading even more "courtship" letters because they were great.

This makes it three stars by the skin of its teeth. I have a reviewing policy that, no matter how many issues I have with a book, if I can answer "yes" to the question "ultimately, are you glad you read this?" it deserves at least three stars. So, even though I think this book has glaring flaws, it was still (barely) worth the time investment for what it did well. 
 This is a book with great world building. I loved being immersed in historical information about a culture that I know nothing about. Said historical information was delivered in a very expository, info dumpy kind of way, but I was OK with that. I found the supernatural setting similarly fascinating. I want to emphasize this is a fantasy novel first, a historical fiction novel second. The majority of the narrative takes place in the Chinese afterlife. The actual details of this afterlife were very interesting to me. 
 So what's the problem? Choo built a great world and then peopled with dull characters and a slack, meandering plot. Great descriptions and historical asides alone can't drive a narrative. Choo built the literary equivalent of a really neat diorama but that's it. The plot has no momentum. The characters are mostly passive and bland. 
 Also, the romantic side plot is totally unsatisfying. It should have been jettisoned. I resent how often authors feel obligated to toss slapdash, half hearted romance into a story when they can't do it well.

This is dark and dramatic but also sweet and moving. Angel is a tragically damaged woman at the start of this book. Orphaned at a young age and sold into sex slavery as a child, she is an understandably embittered adult prostitute when Michael meets her. She is self loathing and self sabotaging, and she lashes out at others because she has learned that kindness = weakness and that any show of vulnerability or even basic humanity will just lead to further victimization and abuse. 
 Michael marries Angel because he receives a call from God to do so. The bulk of the book is focused on Michael's attempts to break down Angel's defenses and accept his unconditional love for her. Michael believes he has a spiritual duty to love Angel, and he treats her with superhuman patience and kindness. He comes to deeply love her outside of the sense of Christian duty that motivated him to marry her. This is a biblical allegory, with Michael's love of Angel representing God's love for humanity. Michael struggles at times to give Angel the type of love she needs, but these struggles have to remain internal because he knows he can't display impatience or short temper with Angel without spooking her off of him. 
 I really appreciated Rivers how wrote Angel's personal redemption. Pain of the type she endured is not quickly cured by the love of a good man, no matter how saintly he is. Her journey towards self acceptance and healing is incremental, and realistic backsliding occurs even after progress is made. She was a very compelling character. Michael is a less dynamic character, but still enjoyable to read about. He is the basically flawless perpetual rock. He's a very sympathetic character, but he isn't 100% realistic. He doesn't have the dimension of Angel, but he was the perfect foil to her. 
 I also enjoyed watching their relationship develop. There's isn't a romance with a lot of heat, but I could totally buy that these characters loved each other. 
 Even though I am an atheist, I do read inspirational fiction which I realize is probably an odd thing to do. I can't speak to how the religious component of this story would work for a devout reader, but I personally found it well written and not off putting or preachy or overly treacly or simplistic at all. This avoids all the potential pitfalls of an inspirational book. You don't have to be even the slightest bit religious to enjoy this. 
 Epilogue nitpicks, (view spoiler)[ of course the supposedly sterile woman has four miracle babies. 
 I also thought the lifelong friendship with Paul thing was odd. Paul was awful. (hide spoiler)]

I enjoyed this a lot even though Ashley busts out the instalove to bring Ian and Beth together, which I typically don't appreciate. I really loved Ian and felt for him. He's a fascinating character. I was moved by his tragic backstory of youthful incarceration in an insane asylum and his present "madness" (which would be recognized in modern times as Asperger's). Beth had a similarly compelling background, having risen from the workhouse, to vicar's wife, to paid ladies companion, to an independent widow of means when she encounters Ian. 
 I loved these characters individually and I loved them together. I could tell they were well suited from the outset. I do wish Ashley had written some more scenes of couple-y bonding that didn't revolved around their mutual lust for each other, but I bought the romance because when Ashley did actually write them talking to each other about things other then their attractiveness and mutual desire, the scenes were well written. 
 This also had a strong non-romance plot revolving around two unsolved murders. I was also intrigued by the glimpses we got of the other Mackenzie brothers. The Mackenzie's are a complicated bunch for sure.

This book is a failure. The characters are fatally underdeveloped, which totally saps the drama out of things. Also, some of the writing is frustratingly vague and hard to follow. 
 However, I can't deny that I found it at times an intriguing failure and I appreciated how weird it was. There were individual moments and bits of prose that really struck me. Taken as a whole this didn't work for me, but bits of it were compelling.

I heart this book and this whole series so much. Bennett is a genius, and I have been so impressed by his skill and creativity. This is excellently paced, packed with tension and action but also plenty of rich character moments. The plot deepens beyond the initial Sigrud avenging Shara's murder intrigue as we get some more crazy divinity action, including (spoiler here ------>) some cannibalism for the kiddies as the murderous god Nokov seeks to gain the powers of his quasi-siblings, the other children of divinity, by killing and eating them. 
 As is par for the course, the writing is beautiful, the characters are compelling, the world building is spectacular, the plot is aces. This also does a great job standing on its own as a distinct, self contained story while also including some satisfying callbacks to what came before in books one and two. 
 Seriously, drop what you're doing and read this series now. Right now. I assure you whatever you're doing is not as worthwhile as reading these books.

Stylistically, I found this book quite witty and well written. India Black had a clever, biting narrative voice that immediately hooked me in. However, style was all this had going for it. The actual meat of the story was totally underwhelming. I was not intrigued or entertained by the plot at all, and no character outside of India leapt off the page to engage me. Even India's charms as a protagonist wear off because her narration, while fun at times, is one note.

This is an intense read. Shreve writes economically yet evocatively. Grace experiences a lot over the course of this relatively slim volume. Before the fire her life is largely confined to her home, caring for her two young children and her taciturn husband Gene. Trips to a visit a friendly neighbor, her widowed mother and the grocery store offer her only respite from the increasingly suffocating nature of her home life. Initially, she considers Gene a decent husband by the standards of his time because he is a good provider but he is cold and his demeanor in the bedroom ranges from brusque to abusive and she becomes increasingly alienated from him. 
 The fire itself is a beautifully written set piece that does a great job establishing the shock, the horror, and the disorientation created by the disaster. The descriptions of the pre-fire drought also provide great foreshadowing. When the fire uproots Grace she is forced to reinvent herself. She has to endure great loss, relocate, provide for her family, and completely reconceptualize what her life is supposed to be. She demonstrates great strength and resilience rebuilding her life, and then (view spoiler)[ surprise! Gene lives after Grace has gotten a new, fulfilling job and had a brief but intense flirtation with a new man. He's horribly scarred and his personality is even more warped then his ruined body. Another curveball. (hide spoiler)] 
 I really enjoyed this and would highly recommend it. It's packed with drama which keeps the pages turning but the tone is grounded. There's drama but not melodrama. My only critique is the enigmatic nature of Gene. He is so removed, and then so barbarous, that he remains a mystery as well as a threat to his wife. However, just because Grace doesn't fully understand him doesn't mean I don't want to as a reader. I wish I had a better sense of what drove him, (view spoiler)[ both to be such a maniac and then to abruptly turn himself around when Grace finally leaves him. I also wish I knew how his mother had acquired her great wealth and any information about his father besides the fact that he was long dead. (hide spoiler)].

Enjoyably twisty and angsty and heart tugging. Initially, Moyes nails the sense of disorientation Jennifer feels as she tries to reacclimate to her life post-head injury induced amnesia. Her decadent surroundings and cold, imperious husband feel as gross and alien to the reader as they do to her. Her affair with "B" is stirring, even though they progress too quickly from "I'm attracted to you" to "I love you forever and forever with an epic, timeless love" (a common handicap of these types of stories). Moyes didn't cheap out with the supporting characters either. They were interesting and real. I particularly loved Moira, the stuffy secretary desperately pining for Larry. She's a minor character yet in a few pages Moyes built a complicated, flawed, tragic woman who I would have been happy to read a whole book about. 
 The modern story doesn't start until 2/3 of the way in but the transition happens smoothly when it does occur and the modern storyline works pretty well. Generally I found this book smartly constructed. Moyes wrote multiple time jumps within the 1960's as well as the jump to 2003 and I never felt like the transitions were awkward. She also did a good job in terms of timing her various plot twists/character reveals.

I loved the first book in this series, These Broken Stars. It was creepy and thought provoking and anchored by a beautifully developed relationship between Lilac and Tarver. Much of the book was intimate in scope as it focused on their personal struggle for survival, but the authors also did an excellent job hinting at bigger things afoot in the universe. 
 Structurally, this book is written similarly to These Broken Stars. We get alternating point of view chapters from the perspective of each of our protagonists intercut with one page interludes that develop a parallel subplot/provide character background. Kaufman and Spooner really nail this particular structure. They do a great job giving Jubilee and Flynn distinctive narrative voices, and the pacing is top notch. These books are nothing if not page turners. Despite the similar structure though, this feels very different from These Broken Stars. Here we get new characters, a new setting, and a book that tonally bears little resemblance to volume one. 
 Jubilee is a hardened military woman tasked with quelling a rebellion on Avon, a swampy backwater planet chafing under the colonial yoke. She alone is considered immune to "the Fury," a murderous battle madness that grips anyone stationed on Avon for long. Flynn is an ambivalent member of that rebellion who captures Jubilee. Over the course of their acquaintance, they shift from enemies to allies as they navigate the morally murky conflict between Jubilee's occupying force and the Avon rebels and investigate the dastardly LaRoux industries (here we get our connection to book one and our Lilac/Tarver cameo). I really dug the plot and I was impressed with how well Kaufman and Spooner wrote about the ongoing war between Jubilee's army and Flynn's people. 
 My only gripe with this is that Kaufman and Spooner felt it necessary to shoehorn in a romance between Jubilee and Flynn that just didn't work for me. I liked them very much individually as characters, and I enjoyed reading their platonic interactions. I buy them as allies, even friends, but I don't buy them as a couple at all. I don't think Kaufman and Spooner really do either. Romance takes a back seat in this volume, which means when it does come up it feels awkwardly shoe horned in rather than organic to the story. It reads as if Kaufman and Spooner would have preferred to write a book sans romance but, due to the demands of their genre were like "OK, we'll throw in some kisses, now let's get back to the good stuff." I wish they could have just jettisoned it entirely because it doesn't read like their heart was into making a romantic connection between Jubilee and Flynn work, and for me it didn't. 
 Still, this was really good and I would highly recommend it. It doesn't pack quite the emotional punch that These Broken Stars did, but it stands well as it's own story and does a good job both expanding on book one and setting up what hopefully will be an excellent book three.

A fascinating yet frustrating read. I thought this had a great premise, and the execution of the premise was strong in the first half of the book. Baru is a child when her home island of Taranoke is colonized by the Empire of Masks. The Empire is repulsed by what they perceive as the savagery and moral turpitude of the Taranoki way of life, most especially their polyamorous, sexually fluid families. Baru is a child of a three parent family, a mother and two fathers, who is taken away from her family to be sent to a school analogous to the boarding schools Native American children were sent to in America to cut them off from their native culture and indoctrinate them into the "American" way of life. One of her fathers is killed. Other residents of Taranoke are physically punished if found to be homosexual, or are forced to participate in eugenics inspired forced breeding or sterilization. They become totally economically dependent on the advanced goods of the Empire. 
 Baru is intelligent enough and cunning enough to excel at her schooling and ace a civil service exam allowing her to work as an imperial accountant within the empire and she schemes to take it down from within to avenge her homeland. What an awesome idea right? Dickinson's treatment of Baru's harrowing childhood was excellent and reading about Baru using her economic cunning to (for example) manufacture ruinous hyper inflation was actually really fun. Dickinson has a lot of clever ideas, and a sophisticated grasp of power dynamics within and between countries. 
 However, the momentum stalled out for me a lot once Baru (view spoiler)[ leaves her post as imperial accountant to become a faux revolutionary (hide spoiler)] The main problem is that most of the characters are so underdeveloped that they are practically indistinguishable from each other. Only Baru and Tain Hu, a rebellious duchess and (view spoiler)[ the object of Baru's deeply repressed lesbian affections (hide spoiler)] approach even two dimensional status. Everyone else is basically just a confusingly named cipher who exists to advance the plot but has no discernible personality. I had the luxury of reading this whole book over the course of one day. I read half of it in one sitting, put it down for about 90 minutes, picked it up again and read the second half. Even with the ability to block out the bulk of my day and read this with minimal distractions/other demands on my time, it was hard at times to keep track of who was who and what was going on as the ensemble cast grew because the characters were so nondescript. So you have two underdeveloped characters, flanked by characters that aren't even one dimensional. Can you have a "zero dimensions" character? If so, Dickinson wrote about a dozen of them. 
 Baru is both by nature and by necessity a cold, closed off person, and tonally the book adopts her remoteness. So as interesting as this book was plot-wise, as I intrigued as I was by some of Dickinson's ideas and by the mechanics of Baru's work, it suffers from diminishing returns as it progresses because of how detached the reader is from every character. (view spoiler)[ The final reveal that Baru's supposed alliance with the rebellion was fake, she was taking the rebels down for the empire so she could get in good with them to carry out her own internal sabotage (hide spoiler)] does not have the emotional punch Dickinson wanted because the protagonist is always an icy robot and nobody else has any identifiable personality traits.

This book is weird. Really, really weird. I guess I would call this a horror version of Alice in Wonderland if I had to call it anything. Or maybe I would call this The Odyssey on all the acid. The lead character Ben goes on a "hike" where all kinds of strange and disturbing wackiness ensues. Everything begins when Ben witnesses a hideous masked man disposing of a child's mutilated body. As he flees this murderer and his accomplice he encounters all kinds of fantastical creatures and bizarre situations as he "stays on the path." 
 This book is creative and unique. Magary writes short, punchy sentences and while his prose is economical, it's also powerful and he writes some very vivid and arresting scenes. His writing is very cinematic. This feels like a book written with a future TV or film adaptation in mind. It would be very easy to translate to a visual medium. 
 The sheer weirdness of this did hold my attention (for a while anyway), and I was curious to see what crazy thing was going to happen next. However, I was put off by the lack of structure and coherence to the narrative. This book was a string of wacky events rather than a traditional narrative. There's not much rhyme or reason to anything. The middle of the book also kind of stalled out for me, as the shock value of the craziness wore off. I like my fantasies with some rules and structure and some world building. Otherwise you just have a grab bag of weird anecdotes strung together, which is what a lot of this book is. The heavily episodic nature of the story means you don't have a lot of characters that you follow over the course of the book which makes it hard for Magary to establish dramatic stakes. I definitely liked things about this but it was also a little too weird for me to fully engage with.

I enjoyed this a lot. Claremont nails the dark, gothic atmosphere. Her writing is very vivid. Eva and Ian were compelling characters and together they were a couple that I really rooted for. The narrative alternates between the present and the past where we get flashbacks fleshing out the relationship between Ian, Eva and Hamilton. In the present Ian, returned from battle in India, is nursing his guilt over the death of Eva's husband and their mutual friend Hamilton and Eva has been institutionalized following the death of her young son (view spoiler)[ who naturally, we find out at the end of the book is not dead, his death was faked by her devious brother (hide spoiler)]. She is kept in horrible circumstances, starved and abused by the asylum workers and addicted to laudanum. When Ian breaks her out of the asylum under false pretenses, Ian and Eva reconnect while trying to evade capture. 
 I appreciated how Claremont wrote Ian and Eva's interactions in both the present and in the flashbacks. In the present Claremont does a good job balancing serious heart to hearts and commiseration over shared tragedy with a few lighter moments of connection. In the flashbacks we learn how these childhood sweethearts were kept apart by a sense of duty to Hamilton's father, and Hamilton himself. For a lot of the book Ian has a somewhat of a "I must control you for your own protection, fragile woman" thing going on but a) it's not really inappropriate given the circumstances (Eva is weakened from the brutal conditions of the asylum, detoxing from laudanum and being pursued by the murderous asylum keeper) and b) by the end of the book Ian actually realizes that his over protectiveness might do more harm than good. 
 There are a few things brushed over a little too quickly en route to the climax (primarily Eva's withdrawal) but I would still highly recommend this.

Before beginning this book, ask yourself this question "Do I like the Gilmore Girls?" Your answer will determine how you feel about this book. There's no connection between the two works in terms of plot, but the tone of this book is incredibly Gilmore Girls-esque. Willis writes all her banter-y dialogue (spoken and telepathically communicated) as if it is coming from the hyper verbal, hyper caffeinated, hyper pop culture referencing mouths of Lorelai and Rory. Briddey's wacky, nosy family and co-workers are very reminiscent of the secondary characters of Stars Hollow. I could not stop thinking about the Gilmore Girls as I read this. If the thought of "science fiction Gilmore Girls, the book" makes you smile, I think you'll enjoy this as much as I did. If that thought makes you recoil, stay far away from this. 
 Much of this book is written as a screwball comedy. Briddey, an executive at a smart phone company, agrees to receive an EED implant to allow direct emotional communication with her boyfriend Trent, who wants her to have the procedure before he proposes. An EED is a brain implant which allows you to read the emotions of an individual you have a strong emotional bond with. Briddey has the procedure done but things go awry. Instead of emotionally bonding with her boyfriend, she finds herself telepathically communicating with her snarky coworker C.B. Much of the book is based around Briddey dealing with her new and unexpected telepathic gifts, which bring her closer to C.B., a long time telepath, and away from Trent. Her telepathy has to be carefully managed. Through him she learns more about why she and C.B. (view spoiler)[ and the other members of her family (hide spoiler)] specifically are telepathic. (view spoiler)[ Willis goes with "an Irish genetic predisposition to telepathy" (hide spoiler)]. The plot eventually gets a bit heavier, as we get our inevitable "the telepaths must hide their gifts from those who seek to exploit them" in the third act but on the whole this stays pretty light. 
 I thought this book was a lot of fun. I enjoyed the breezy tone and found a lot of the verbal pyrotechnics clever. The "science" in this science fiction is pretty light lifting, which is fine by me as I like my science fiction on the soft side, but the plot is plenty entertaining. Your suspension of disbelief has to be high to appreciate this but if you can get on Willis's zany wavelength it's quite delightful. I really appreciated how Willis wrote Briddey and C.B.'s relationship. She did an excellent job making me care about these characters and their relationship, even though there are some troublesome aspects to how C.B. treats Briddey (why yes, there is some paternalistic "I need to guide and protect you and thus lie to you") business. Man did I love their scene in the library. Willis also does an great job capturing the frantic feeling of communication overload. 
 Some of the humor was overly broad and repetitive. Briddey's sisters are one note characters, and Willis strikes that one note over and over and over (boy crazy for the wrong men! hysterically overprotective helicopter mother!). We get it already, move on. The payoff for Aunt Oona was funny though. 
 There's not a lot of heft to this book, but it's fun light read.

3.5 stars. This won't win any awards for originality but Stuart's skillful execution of some admittedly well worn tropes was pleasing to me as a reader. Stuart writes well, her plotting is brisk and she packs plenty of intrigue into 270 pages. We've got secret identities and double crosses, murder and other assorted mayhem, marital infidelities, secret accidental funding of Irish terrorism, and of course the steadily increasing sexual tension between Bryony and Adrian as Bryony goes undercover as a housekeeper in Adrian's household to investigate the death of her unjustly disgraced father. 
 The romance is based primarily on flirtation and sexual attraction. There's lots of fun banter and heat and longing. Generally, I would like a romance story to feature a longer courtship and a more substantive connection between the leads beyond the carnal but in this case I enjoyed Briony and Adrian's dynamic even if I acknowledge it was kind of shallow. I liked Briony and Adrian a lot as individual characters, and I totally bought into their compatibility. 
 I look forward to continuing this series.

A sweet romance that is jam packed with historical detail about the Reconstruction era West. Rhine, a minor character in Jenkins's Through the Storm, is a wealthy saloon owner and Republican councilman who is the biracial son of a slave master and his slave. He is light skinned enough to pass as white, which he does. When he meets Eddy she is near death after being burgled en route to California to work as a cook and hopefully open her own restaurant. They have a strong attraction to each other, but Eddy refuses to indulge it believing she can never be with a "white" man and Rhine is yoked to a rich, white fiancee acquired to further his political ambitions and faces the loss of his white privilege if confesses his true racial lineage to be with Eddy. 
 This doesn't have a fast paced, action packed plot but Jenkins does such a good job making her characters and Virginia City come alive that all the details feel important and the pace doesn't drag. There are also plenty of supporting characters and subplots to keep things interesting. Eddy recuperates from her attack in the desert and then settles into Virginia City as a boardinghouse cook. She becomes close with several residents of the town and is briefly and unsuccessfully courted by another man. Rhine goes to council meetings, hits on Eddy to no avail, runs his businesses, is an active crusader for civil rights, and deals with his crazy fiancee. Rhine and Eddy have excellent chemistry when their paths intersect, bantering and flirting. More than anything else, I just really enjoyed spending time in the world Jenkins created as a reader. Jenkins does a good job making them interesting characters as individuals as well as teasing their romance. There's not too much sexual content but what is there is hot. 
 I feel like romance novels are generally formulaic enough not to require spoiler tags but I will be talking about the ending in general terms so if you're exceptionally spoiler sensitive do not read on. Vague sort of spoilers start now ------>. My only criticism is I do think the ending is too abrupt. I wish we had seen more of Rhine and Eddy actually as a couple and I think the consequences of Rhine deciding to no longer pass as white are too quickly brushed aside. I would also think Rhine's revelation would necessitate a move that doesn't happen.

This book is just pure fun. From page one to the last I was totally riveted by all the political and interpersonal intrigue. Peggy is such a devious anti-hero, I loved reading about her. All the other characters, from the rest of the Shippen family to Benedict Arnold to the servants are great fun to read about as well. The plot is excellently paced and structured and the descriptions are detailed enough to provide great historical color but they never bog the story down. So happy I read this.

The analytical part of my brain screams "this is cheesy, contrived, trash." There's corny dialogue, cliched melodrama, and bar none one of the stupidest plot twists I have ever read. I am of course referring to the (view spoiler)[ surprise! Julia's "dead" husband Xavier lives! (hide spoiler)] silliness. WTF. However, as much of the thinking, reasoning, part of me was fully cognizant of what a tire fire this book is, I can't pretend I didn't enjoy reading it. I love a good historical soap opera that spans multiple generations and as stupid as this book was in parts, I also found it fun and entertaining. Enjoyment beat out irritation at the ludicrousness of what I was reading. 
 In the present we have Julia, a renowned classical pianist dealing with the death of her family, and being romanced by Kit, the inheritor of the Wharton estate. No one in this book has a normal job. Imagine if Julia had been an accountant or a paralegal or a cashier. The characters have to be wealthy and "artistic" enough to sulk for months in their picturesque estates and country cottages without any practical concerns intruding on the melodrama. Kit is similarly tortured by lost love and unencumbered by the day to day cares of an actual person. Of course, they quickly fall in love despite Julia's supposed despondency. Their relationship made me feel warm and fuzzy and roll my eyes at the same time. 
 Julia's grandparents were in service at the Wharton estate, and her grandmother's reminisces over a relocated diary send the reader back into the past, where we read about Harry Crawford's legitimate (WWII captivity) and not so legitimate (poor little rich boy doesn't want to inherit and run giant estate and marry a society lady) problems. While convalescing in Thailand he falls in love with a Thai teenager because he loves her skinny, delicate body and her reticence about speaking English makes her less mouthy than his wife Olivia. Yup. That's an aspirational love story for the ages right there. All of this is after Harry thinks he's gay and then decides, eh, no after macking on a school mate. Alright. There are of course spooky secrets from the past, i.e. (view spoiler)[ babies with secret parentage (hide spoiler)] 
 I enjoyed MST3King this book as I was reading it a great deal. I also derived sincere enjoyment from some of the cloying writing and overripe intrigue because I'm a sap who's easily emotionally manipulated. This book did move me at points, which I should probably be embarrassed about but I'm not.

What's most striking about this book is how beautifully written it is, and how the author's prose creates such an effective melancholy atmosphere. This novel is set in the distant future, in Chinese controlled Scandinavia, where global warming caused flooding and protracted resource wars and oil and potable water shortages have left what's left of the world poor and beholden to restrictive military rule. The protagonist Noria is a young tea master who over the course of the book deals with learning her father's trade and then learning to cope with his death, guarding a secret water source, surreptitiously assisting a close friend and her family who are in perpetually dire straits as military surveillance steadily increases and the discovery of a puzzling and troubling mystery from a "twilight century" of disappeared history. 
 Dystopian novels have been very trendy for the last several years, meaning the market is been glutted with a lot of interchangeable books that feel like they've been rolled off an assembly line. I appreciated how much this book avoided the tropes of the genre and actually felt distinctive. 
 This is an intimate story. The cast of characters is small, there's not a lot of exposition, and plot is low on action, relying instead on the slow escalation of tension. I found it a nice change of pace to read a book like this where the protagonist isn't a shiny, special chosen one, and her problems, while serious, are grounded in her personal circumstances rather than a large scale "OMG the world is ending and only I can stop it" impending apocalypse or rebellion. The small scale nature of this story did mean that in a few instances the world building wasn't as thorough as I would have liked, but there was plenty that was intriguing to me about this world even if it was somewhat underdeveloped. 
 Also, the author didn't feel obligated to shoe horn in a romance and/or love triangle. This restraint is highly appreciated.

Reading this is like watching a deranged baby play with its dirty diaper. It's obvious all McGuire is interested in as an author is writing graphic descriptions of bodily excretions periodically punctuated by graphic descriptions of murders. I have never read an author so scatologically obsessed in my life, and I read a lot. If I edited out all the times McGuire describes how badly the air stinks of piss and/or crap and/or blood there wouldn't be enough book left to fill a pamphlet. 
 This book is constantly, ostentatiously, gratuitously crude. It is obvious McGuire is laboring to shock and disgust the reader with the grossness of the characters' surroundings but he has such a heavy hand that the reader quickly becomes desensitized and bored. This book's sole narrative purpose is to make the reader think "eww, icky" which is juvenile in the extreme. There is no variation in tone, no nuance or dimension to McGuire's writing. Character development is nonexistent, there's no plot to speak of. There's no tension or suspense whatsoever. All we have is page after page of purple prose devoted to describing the gross miasma of the whaling ship and the many scents and sounds of evacuation. 
 I hated this book. It has no redeeming value whatsoever. I want to take a shower and forget I ever read it.

The Association of Small Bombs is a book of compelling moments, well written imagery, and strong individual scenes but it does not have a well structured overarching plot, and some important characters seem to have truncated or nonexistent arcs. The only real connective tissue of the story, the glue holding everything together, is Mansoor, the survivor of the 1996 bomb who is later (view spoiler)[ arrested and imprisoned as an accomplice to the 2003 bombing committed his friend Ayub (hide spoiler)]. Taken as a whole, his story is a tragic gut punch, though I had quibbles with how quickly Mahajan writes the final part of his story (he tries to cover way too much ground in about 10 pages of text). 
 Sadly, I found Shockie and Ayub, (view spoiler)[ the terrorists behind the "associated small bombs" in 1996 and 2003 respectively (hide spoiler)] dull characters. I felt at such a remove from both of them and their chapters were a chore. (view spoiler)[ I am very open to reading books that get into the mind of terrorists. I am even open as a reader to feeling some level of empathy for a terrorist character, but I felt like with the transformation of Ayub chapters Mahajan was just checking off boxes on a checklist and writing with such remove that I couldn't get invested (hide spoiler)]. Vikas and Deepa, the parents of Mansoor's slain friends, were potentially interesting characters but they're grafted onto the story in a very ungainly way. The books opens on their pain at the loss of their sons, then they're dropped completely from the story as we follow other characters, then periodically re-inserted in seemingly random fashion. I'm also not convinced either of them had much of a journey as a character despite the strength of some of their scenes. 
 I think this is book where the author's reach exceeds his grasp. A lot of Mahajan's writing is quite striking and thought provoking but I also couldn't shake the feeling that there was something missing from this as I was reading it.

I liked this book a lot, hence the four star rating, but I would only recommend this for readers in the mood for a very twisted tale. 
 This book is creepy from page one. It is consistently unsettling. There's this icky fever dream quality to the whole thing. Abbott's highly stylized writing, which I largely loved though it was occasionally confusing, and the frequent interjection of Lizzie's dreams into the story create this otherworldly horror atmosphere. Evie's kidnapping is in and of itself disturbing, and Abbott soaks every page with this dark, foreboding, sordid atmosphere. Reading this is an intense sensory experience. 
 The resolution of Evie's story is well foreshadowed, powerful and dramatically satisfying, as dark and gross as it is. Detailed spoilers about the ending under the tag. (view spoiler)[ Evie is motivated by her sexual jealousy of her sister Dusty's inappropriate relationship to their father to initiate a relationship with a forty year old man. Dusty is similarly aggressive in asserting her proprietary interest in their father. Portraying Evie and Dusty as such seemingly "willing" victims of predatory adult men will probably be a controversial narrative choice for some readers. I don't think Abbott is engaging in victim blaming or arguing that Evie and Dusty are morally responsible for their own victimization though. She writes a detailed description of Evie's first rape which makes Shaw's moral culpability crystal clear despite Evie's misguided "desire" for him. She also shows how Mr. Verver has disgustingly groomed his children to make them "want" relationships with adult men, just as he grooms Lizzie over the course of Evie's disappearance. For these reasons, I have no problem with Abbott writing Evie as a girl who "wanted" to be raped and Dusty as a girl who "wants" to have an incestuous relationship with her father. I found the severity and complexity of the dysfunction fascinating as a reader. (hide spoiler)] 
 My only quibble is I do wish Abbott went into Evie's head a bit more though and explored her thoughts/feelings in more detail. We see this very twisted dynamic through Lizzie's eyes rather than through Evie's, although (view spoiler)[ Mr. Verver's gross innuendos towards Lizzie (hide spoiler)] give us a strong sense of how (view spoiler)[ his perversion (hide spoiler)] has warped all three girls so badly. 
 If you are in the mindset for a dark read I would definitely recommend this.

This book could have very easily been terrible. The characters are all super privileged, and their "problems" such as they are are self made and/or problems of affluence. Close asks you to sympathize with "struggles" like "my lucrative, prestigious job is not exactly the job I want, how I suffer" or "my husband doesn't help me enough with our kid even though we're rich enough to have hired help, live right next to doting family and all I do work wise is a goofy, part-time hobby job selling jewelry to my vapid, bitchy friends." It's hard for an author to create high stakes narratively when everyone is so well off. Even when things get heavier with the marital problems between Beth/Matt and Jim/Ash as they are put through the wringer of a political campaign the reader always sees the safety nets the characters have that ensure true disaster will never strike. 
 This seems like a pretty negative start to a four star review I realize. I start this way only to show how easily this book could have gone awry. It's a minor miracle that it doesn't. Despite writing in the difficult genre of "upper class people dealing with their extremely first world problems" this book is actually really good. Close is a consistently witty writer. Her wry observational eye make this a joy to read. Stylistically, her writing is a treat. 
 I don't know D.C. well (I've taken a few short trips there but never spent real time in the city) so this is a guess on my part but this book also feels super authentic in its discussions of what it would be like for these specific characters to live in D.C. If it is as realistic as it feels I congratulate Close for doing such a good job recreating the social milieu of White House staffers and their families. If it's not, I congratulate her anyway for simulating authenticity so well. 
 The main characters are not very sympathetic in a "I'd like to know these people" way but they are interesting people who command your attention on the page. Their relationships are textured and compelling. Close does a good job writing complex friendships, marriages and workplace relationships. The secondary characters are also vivid and entertaining. I'm not of the belief characters have to be likable to create a good reading experience. If you need likable protagonists I'd skip this one but if you're fine reading about some fairly obnoxious people as long as the writing itself is of high quality, I'd recommend this. 
 This book also is very much a page turner. I read 200+ pages of it in one sitting. I liked it a lot and would strongly recommend it.

This book is the literary equivalent of a hug. It is just so sweet and the emotional impact of the romance is so strong because George and Dora are such loving and lovely characters. 
 Tonally, this whole series reminds me of a beloved show of mine, Call the Midwife. Balogh handles tragedy with tenderness and empathy, and writes most of her characters as individuals who conduct themselves with quiet dignity and decency. There is a warmth that radiates off of each page that is totally intoxicating to the reader. 
 George is a 48 year old widower, long single after his first wife's suicide following the death of their child in the Napoleonic Wars. Dora is a 39 year old spinster who has settled into a quiet life of music instruction after family scandal permanently postponed her debut and left her in charge of the upbringing of her much younger sister. 
 After finally tiring of his solitude, George impulsively proposes marriage to Dora, promising kindness and companionship if not great romance. So this book traces a post marriage courtship, as George and Dora fall in love with each other after they've been joined together in matrimony. Watching their love bloom is absolutely delightful. George and Dora are characters both strongly motivated by feelings of duty and self sacrifice, which prevented them from finding love earlier in life, and George struggles with guilt over the dysfunctional state of his first family. 
 Watching these characters grow together and find the love they so richly deserve was so satisfying and joyful. This book is the perfect literary pick me up that charms the pants off of you from page one. What a perfect conclusion to the series.
A likable enough book but sluggishly paced

This is the ninth Sanderson book I've sat down to read and the first that I didn't like. I read half of it and just couldn't get into it at all. I found it so dull. After enjoying the first two volumes so much I was shocked by how much this one didn't work for me. I'm just going to google spoilers to see how everything turns out.

This was real cool. Sanderson starts with a strong premise. It's very realistic (that's right, I'm calling a book about people who suddenly get super powers realistic) that newly created "epics," would become so warped by their power that they would be at best indifferent to regular human life and at worst actively murderous. Power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely. Regular people would be like ants to super beings. 
 So the main showdown in this book is between the Reckoners, a dedicated band of epic assassins, and Steelheart, the epic ruler of Newcago. We follow new reckoner recruit David, seeking to avenge his murdered father. David is a bit too implausibly knowledgeable and perfect but I guess that comes with the territory with this type of book. 
 This is quite the fast paced read. It's pretty action-y which isn't usually my thing but Sanderson writes well enough for me to get into it for the most part. As the book goes on Sanderson not only delivers a clever, propulsive plot but he injects more moral complexity and nuance into the narrative. He also writes strong individual character moments for David, lead reckoner Prof and my favorite character Megan. 
 Highly recommended.

I continue to heart this series. Balogh has a knack for writing well developed characters that the audience develops a strong attachment to. She doesn't bother with melodrama, or contrived misunderstandings, or plot propelling stupidity. She trusts that she can captivate her readers by chronicling the lives and loves of fundamentally good people working through their grief, growing as individuals, and falling in love in a mature, thoughtful way.

Most of this book was a four star read for me but I found the final act (the last 50-60 pages) so muddled and confusing I'm knocking a star off. 
 I thought Hodge did a really good job maintaining a consistently creepy atmosphere. This book is really dark and unsettling at times. The Gentle Lord's castle is a fantastic set piece. This is the literary equivalent of a haunted house movie because so much of the plot is driven by Nyx's explorations of this gigantic, sprawling, fearsome castle. Nyx, Ignifex, and Shade are all interesting characters with complicated motivations. I really appreciated how Nyx wasn't all pure and noble and self sacrificing but was appropriately bitter about her lot in life. I didn't really buy into the love triangle between Nyx, Ignifex, and Shade but it didn't detract from all the other things I was enjoying about the story. 
 However, as the climax of the book approaches things went off the rails for me. By the end the plot had become pretty convoluted with all the magical artifacts and mythological allusions and shifting alliances and the resolution to all this craziness, the whole (view spoiler)[ time unwinding thing (hide spoiler)] just left me scratching my head. I didn't understand the mechanics of that at all. (view spoiler)[ How was Nyx even alive in the first place if the last 900 years hadn't happened? She only exists in the first place because of the bargain between her father and the gentle lord. Shouldn't the world be totally different in every way? (hide spoiler)] I was just a pile of confusion from that plot point to the end. I really don't think this book needed the introduction of that type of plot element given how much was already going on. That's right, I'm a 31 year old grown ass adult admitting I couldn't follow the conclusion of a YA fantasy novel. Beyond that, (view spoiler)[ The final showdown between Nyx and the kindly ones was pretty meh to me as well (hide spoiler)]

A fun bit of fluff. Though the male protagonist of this story is a vampire, don't come into this expecting a dark and scary read. The tone of this book is light and sweet. Though Ian (view spoiler)[ is almost killed by Ben the vampire hunter (hide spoiler)] and Angelica is (view spoiler)[ kidnapped by a vampire named Rosetta acting to protect John Polidori, author of "The Vampyre" (hide spoiler)] these potentially grave problems are completely resolved with ridiculous quickness and don't alter the breezy tone Ann affects throughout. 
 This book doesn't have a lot of depth to it in terms of plot, world building or characterization but if you go in ready for a light entertainment it's got charm. The premise is solid, Ian and Angelica are cool characters who have a fun relationship to read about, Ann writes good dialogue. I really enjoyed Angelica's attempts to repel Ian and how miserably they failed because he *gasp* actually wanted a bookish proto-feminist.

I'm mostly on vacation this week so I decided this was a good time to dig into Megan Abbott, an author who had been on my radar a long time but who I hadn't actually read. I kicked off Abbott week with her latest work, You Will Know Me, a very well written and psychologically astute mystery set in the world of elite gymnastics. After reading and enjoying that book so thoroughly, I dove right into Dare Me, a dark and twisted tale of adultery, murder and really bitchy cheerleaders. 
 I enjoyed this. I like how Abbott writes stylistically. She uses distinctive descriptive language and does a great job creating vivid imagery without overwriting. She's witty too. I also think she did a good job capturing the way teen girls can be so smotheringly close to each other and so mean and destructive simultaneously. 
 However, this did also leave me wanting more. I thought this book could have easily been a hundred pages longer. Specifically I wanted more scenes of the coach enslaving the team to her cruel charisma, focusing on how she balanced her meanness with star power and persuasiveness to get everyone but Beth to buy in, more Beth and Addy scenes, and further development of coach's relationship to both her husband and Will. There's too much summarizing instead of showing how these characters interact with each other. I never really could grasp the source of the coach's power. 
 Also, every character is so terrible, a little variation in tone and characterization would have been appreciated. I have no problem with dark books, dark material and unsympathetic characters but nobody lives in a world where every single person in their life is completely awful all the time.

This book had some contrivances that I found super annoying. I found the way everyone treated Alice, sufferer of a very serious head injury, totally unrealistic. She just plops back into her life despite losing a decade of memories and no one directly communicates with her about the ten years she loses or even seems particularly alarmed about her condition. No one sits her down and says "OK, let me tell you what you're not remembering...and maybe you shouldn't be tending children, driving and baking giant novelty pies (yes, there's a giant pie subplot) while coping with mysterious brain damage." She's half heartedly told to see a doctor twice maybe and that's it. 
 Moriarty also doesn't do a completely satisfactory job of answering the question "why did Alice change so much?" which is kind of the whole frigging point of the book. She spends so much time teasing us with mysteries that wouldn't be so mysterious if people just had mutually beneficial straightforward conversations with each other that Alice's actual transformation arc gets relegated to a small section of the overall text. To say Alice is a poorly developed character is an overstatement but a 460 page character study could have and should have done this better. We get a good sense of certain parts of her devolution but not all of it. Maybe if we didn't waste so much time reading stupid letters from Frannie we could have gotten to it. 
 Despite these problems, which are significant, this book is a super page turner. I read three quarters of it in one sitting. Moriarty did a great job creating in me a thirst to keep learning more about these characters and to solve the two major puzzles she introduces "why did Alice and Nick split up?" and "what's the deal with this Gina person that everyone keeps talking about in hushed tones?" Again, in the real world Alice would just have those questions answered for her in a five minute conversation and there'd be no book but my awareness of the contrived nature of these mysteries didn't totally dampen my enjoyment. 
 Softie that I am, I can't give a book that really compelled me to keep turning the pages less than 3 stars no matter how many nitpicks I have. Of the four Moriarty books I've read (this, The Husband's Secret, Big Little Lies, and The Last Anniversary) this is the weakest but for all its flaws this book is hard to put down and for me that counts for a lot in terms of how I rate a book. This is the kind of book that really casts a spell over you and demands you keep reading no matter how frustrated you get at times by its shortcomings.

This book is a pure joy to read. The main plotline is perfect: Jane and Oliver are great characters individually and a couple. I was totally invested in them. All the scenes of Jane's calculated social suicide were so fun to read. What a bold, distinctive heroine. Oliver burns with by steely ambition and righteousness but this fire is tempered by a passivity and fear borne of his acute awareness of his own precarious social status. How can this man, so conscious of his need to marry well, avoid controversy, and curry favor with parliament to advance his noble ideological objectives court a woman who has deliberately destroyed her own reputation to protect her sister and her fortune? 
 In addition to to this excellent main plot, this book is distinguished by its rich subplots, supporting characters and historical detail.
