This book chronicles four relationships at different stages of their development (from a quick affair to a forty year marriage), and through at least some of them hits on some pretty interesting points about how couples manage the joys and stresses of married life. These relationship narratives are framed by the sorry of Frances Gerety, the advertiser who coined the slogan "Diamonds are Forever". Here is how I would rank the sections in terms of quality, from best to worst: Evelyn/1972, James/1987, Frances 1947-88, Kate/2012, Delphine/2003. The best plot lines are really well developed, but the two weakest plots are tedious (Kate) and eye gougingly annoying (Delphine).

Reading this book is like walking around in a really cool, well curated diorama. It is great fun to hang out in this world and soak up the ambience and all the details surrounding the cult of reclusive director Stanislav Cordova. His daughter's death is investigated by disgraced journalist Scott McGrath, aspiring actress and coat check girl Nora Halliday and lovelorn drug dealer Hopper. There was obviously a lot of care and creativity put into constructing this story. Everything simultaneously feels authentic and other worldly. The alternative film history is awesome and the tone of the book is appropriately very film noir. 
 The stylistic gimmick of including documents in text, such as magazine and blog posts, photos etc really comes off as well. These really enrich the text. 
 My only nitpick is I thought this had one too many endings.
Nuanced and compelling. I was totally sucked into this story from page one to the end. The character development was top notch and the writing style was perfect.
Fascinating, horrifying, unputdownable. Very educational and insightful. Surprisingly beautifully written given the grim subject matter. What a story and what an accomplished telling of it.

To be cliched, this is the ultimate "you'll laugh, you'll cry" type of reading experience. What an unputdownable emotional roller coaster. 
 This book is ridiculously witty and clever, with prose and dialogue that is regularly laugh out funny and deeply insightful. When I started the book it almost seemed too clever to me, the level of verbal gymnastics seemed a bit forced, but ultimately the beauty of the language and the richness of the story makes these hyper literate, hyper articulate characters work. They still feel real and authentic. I was awed by how this book contained some very powerful, beautiful and resonant observations about life and mortality yet it also smartly punctured a lot of the false, feel good myths we tell ourselves to try to handle the horror and senselessness of death. 
 Given the subject matter it is not surprising that this book is also a tear jerker but the sentiment is earned. I teared up at at least half a dozen parts of this book and fully cried at the end. 
 I highly recommend this book because it deftly balanced comedic and dramatic elements and created vivid, engaging and loveable but not cloying characters. 
 Awesome.

I found the first half of this book underwhelming: I thought too much time was spent in the present, which was very generic chick lit, and some aspects of the time travel bugged me (how easily the men accepted the presence of a time traveling modern woman and how incurious they were about the future, how neither Eva or Daniel struggle much with time travel logistically and/or philosophically). However I must confess the second half of the book won me over with its charm and sweetness, despite the narrative problems. This books grows on you, and Eva and Daniel have a blessedly warm, non-annoying romance. It is sort of thin and shallow but also genuinely heartwarming so I give it three stars for the emotional engagement I felt with the second half of the narrative and for the beautiful descriptions of Cornwall.

I can't believe Margaret Atwood wrote this. The 175 pages of this I read before I made the decision to abandon it were shockingly terrible. The first two books are so good, don't taint them by picking up this volume. Yikes.

Provided you're willing to accept the artificiality of this book's implausible plot and hyper stylized, show-offy prose, this is a really fun read. It's creative and engrossing and anchored by a great protagonist in Blue. 
 Pessl's distinctive writing style also largely worked for me. Her constant stream of references, parenthetical asides, and lengthy, colorful descriptions will definitely not be to everyone's taste but I found this witty and well crafted for the most part.

A significant improvement over the Gunslinger. Roland is still kind of a drip of a character but thankfully the new members of the ensemble are vivid and interesting. This story is very satisfying in its own right and sets up the next book nicely.

2.5 stars. A really mixed bag. I really liked the premise and how the plot developed but the characterizations and interpersonal relationships were pretty anemic. My interest in the world itself was piqued, I liked both the war of the gods backstory as well as the current descriptions of Sky and Darr, but I didn't connect to any of the characters or care about them. The dreamy, reflective first person narration (Yeine is recalling this story at some undetermined point in the future) was also something I blew hot and cold on.

This is one of those books where as you read you're fully cognizant of narrative flaws (the implausibility of many plot points, the predictability of the twist ending, the way the author doesn't do more than skim the surface of her characters' psyches) but you just can't stop reading. A highly entertaining albeit superficial page turner.
This book had consistently vivid and evocative imagery, some great scenes and it hinted at lots of cool stuff, but I also had some problems with it.
